Task: extract all food–polyphenol–quantity triples from the following paragraph.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
When comparing cultivars and ripeness stages, ripe cv. Saco sweet cherries showed a total phenolic content of 264 mg/100 g fw, in contrast to partially ripe cv Van sweet cherries, which contained only 69 mg/100 g fw.

Task: extract all food–polyphenol–quantity triples from the following paragraph.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Anthocyanins have been recognized as health-enhancing substances due to their antioxidant activity, anti-inflammatory, anticancer, and hypoglycemic effects. They have been found to be absorbed from the gut into the bloodstream and were detected in the urine at 1.0–6.7 % of the total amount when six healthy human subjects drank 300 mL of a red wine containing 218 mg of anthocyanins. The world production of anthocyanins has been estimated at 10000 tonnes from grapes alone, and the average daily intake has been estimated at 215 mg in summer and 180 mg in winter, underlining their importance in the human diet.
red wine | anthocyanins | 218 | mg/300 mL

Task: extract all food–polyphenol–quantity triples from the following paragraph.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
The amount of flavanols in garlic and white and red onions was reported as approximately 6, 4, and 5 mg of CE/100 g DW, respectively. These levels are lower but still comparable to previously published values for garlic and onions. In contrast, some vegetables such as broad bean can reach up to 184 mg/100 g DW of total flavanols. Regarding anthocyanins, raw white onion contained about 28 mg of CGE/kg DW, whereas raw red onion reached around 460 mg of CGE/kg DW, confirming much higher levels in the red cultivar. Literature ranges indicate that anthocyanins in red onions can vary between 317 and 1951 mg of CGE/kg DW, while in white onions they span from 5.69 to 333 mg of CGE/kg DW. In garlic, anthocyanins were not detected.
"garlic | flavanols | 6 | mg of CE/100 g DW

Our measurements showed olive oil containing polyphenols (total) at 180. ppm, whereas previously reported values for olive oil have ranged from 104–516 ppm for polyphenols (total, literature). The difference between 180. ppm and the 104–516 ppm span likely reflects variations in cultivar, processing, and analytical methodology.

Task: extract all food–polyphenol–quantity triples from the following paragraph.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
In dietary terms, bell peppers contribute substantially to the intake of antioxidant vitamins A and C. Their major flavonoids are quercetin and luteolin, which are present mainly as conjugated derivatives. Lee et al. (27) reported that, after hydrolysis, total flavonoids in yellow pepper fruit spanned a range from non detectable up to 800 mg/kg. All of the yellow pepper fruit samples they analyzed showed high flavonoid contents. Among the twelve pepper cultivars studied, quercetin concentrations were 2–12 times greater than those of luteolin, yet luteolin exhibited the strongest antioxidant activity, followed by capsaicin and then quercetin when compared on an equivalent basis.
yellow pepper fruit | total flavonoids | 0-800 | mg/kg

Task: extract all food–polyphenol–quantity triples from the following paragraph.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
In the hydroxycinnamic acid fraction of sweet cherries, neochlorogenic acid was clearly predominant. In ripe fruits it ranged from 22 to 190 mg/100 g of fw and accounted for 19–71% of total phenolics, whereas in partially ripe fruits it ranged from 19 to 126 mg/100 g of fw, representing 24–72% of the phenolics. For the same cultivar, p-coumaroylquinic and chlorogenic acids showed comparable concentrations during ripening and storage. The p-coumaroylquinic acid content varied between 4 and 34 mg/100 g of fw, corresponding to 4% of total phenolics in cv. Van and 27% in cv. Summit. Chlorogenic acid ranged from 3 to 12 mg/100 g of fw and contributed 2% of the phenolics in cv. Van and 4% in cv. Saco. Other hydroxycinnamic acids each contributed less than 2% of total phenolics.

cv. Saco sweet cherries | chlorogenic acid | 4 | % of total phenolics
sweet cherries | other hydroxycinnamic acids | <2 | % of total phenolics

As anticipated, the technological processing applied to garlic and onions resulted in a reduction of both bioactive compounds and antioxidant activity, with the magnitude of loss depending on the type and duration of the treatment. Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC) Assay. The ORAC assay was performed using a fluorescence plate reader (28). The measurements were carried out on a FLUOstar OPTIMA plate reader (BMG Labtech GmbH, Offenburg, Germany) using the 485 nm excitation and the 520 nm emission filters. Fluorescein (120 $\mu$ L; 70 nM final concentration) was the fluorescent substrate and AAPH (60 $\mu$ L; 24 mM final concentration) the source for peroxyl radicals. The reaction was conducted in 75 mM potassium phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, at 37 °C with Trolox (2 $\mu$ M) as control standard and phosphate buffer as blank. The extracts were automatically diluted to four concentrations in duplicates by Biomek 2000 Workstation (Beckman Coulter, Fullerton, CA), and 20 $\mu$ L of samples, blanks, and Trolox were added to a black 96-well microplate (96F, Nunc, Roskilde, Denmark). The fluorescein fluorescence was recorded every 3 min after the addition of AAPH until the fluorescence was <5% of the initial reading. Final results were calculated using the differences of areas under the fluorescein decay curves between the blank and a sample and were expressed as micromoles of Trolox equivalents (TE) per gram of fresh weight (µmol of TE/g of fw).

In the phenolic profile of raw lentils, catechins and proanthocyanidins dominated, representing 69% of all identified phenolics with a total concentration of 74. µg/g. The chief constituent of this subgroup was (+)-catechin 3-glucoside (39. µg/g), with a procyanidin trimer and procyanidin B2 as the next most abundant compounds. These data agree with earlier reports by Escarpa and González (27), Amarowicz and Karamac (28), and Martín-Cabrejas et al. (7), although, in contrast to Dueñas et al. (24), prodelphinidins were not detected in raw lentils. Industrial dehydration led to major reductions in these phenolics: (+)-catechin 3-glucoside underwent a sharp decline of 95%, and most procyanidins disappeared by the end of processing. The applied heat treatments, including cooking and dehydration, likely induce degradation of highly polymerized proanthocyanidins, cleavage of glycosidic bonds in flavonoids, and decomposition of aglycones (10, 29). Consistent with this, air-drying at temperatures exceeding 60 °C is generally viewed as detrimental for phenolic extraction efficiency because of oxidative condensation and loss of thermolabile (+)-catechins (32).

Vegetables are the most important sources of phenolics in the Mediterranean diet. Phenolics, especially flavonoids, are suggested as being essential bioactive compounds providing health benefits. In this study, twenty-seven vegetables, fifteen aromatic herbs and some spices consumed in Central Italy (the Marches region) were studied to reveal total phenolic, flavonoid and flavanol content as well as their anti-oxidant capacity measured by the oxygen radical absorbance capacity (ORAC) method. A comparison in terms of antioxidant capacity was made between different salads, as well as between salads to which aromatic herbs had been added. Lemon balm and marjoram at a concentration of 1. % w/w increased by 150 % and 200 % respectively the antioxidant capacity of a salad portion. A 200 g portion of a salad enriched with marjoram corresponded to an intake of 200 (sd 10) mg phenolics and 4000 (sd 300) ORAC units (µmol Trolox equivalents). Olive oils and wine or apple vinegars were the salad dressings that provided the highest increase in antioxidant capacity. Among the spices tested, cumin and fresh ginger made the most significant contribution to the antioxidant capacity. The results are useful in surveying the antioxidant parameters of vegetables, herbs and spices produced and consumed in our geographical area as well as in quantifying the daily intake of phenolics and ORAC units. The results can be used in public health campaigns to stimulate the consumption of vegetables able to provide significant health protection in order to prevent chronic diseases.

The antioxidant activity of bran extracts against copper-induced LDL oxidation was significantly higher than that of whole grain or flour. The total amount of phenolic compounds in cereals was reported to be very low, only 0.2-1. mg gallic acid equivalents/g of crude phenolic extract (41). Kahkonen et al. (41) also described low antioxidant activity of cereal extracts, even at 5000 ppm, in the methyl linoleate oxidation system. These low TPC values may reflect the fact that only free phenolics were quantified. In cereals, however, most phenolic compounds are present in bound form associated with cell wall materials (10-13, 42-44). The present study confirmed that bound phenolics contribute substantially to the TPCs of whole grains, flours, and brans of both soft and hard wheats. Consequently, cereals may appear to have low TPCs if only free phenolic acids are measured. Dewanto et al. (45) reached a similar conclusion for corn, emphasizing the dominance of bound phenolics. Sosulski et al. (10) reported that 69.2% of wheat TPCs arise from insoluble-bound phenolics and that soluble conjugated phenolic acids in cereal flours are 2-5 times higher than the corresponding free phenolic acids.

The simultaneous determination of 19 phenolic compounds was performed directly in wort and beer by a combination of reverse-phase high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with coulometric array detection. Chromatographic separation was achieved with an appropriate gradient of flow and a binary solvent based on phosphate buffer, methanol, and acetonitrile in a 45-min run. Eight serial coulometric detectors were used for on-line generation of voltammetric data to resolve coeluting compounds. The method was reliable and sensitive, the regression coefficient of standard calibration curves is $0. \le r \le 1.000$ , and the standard deviation value ranges from 0. to 0. mg/L for wort and from 0. to 0. mg/L for beer. The mean concentrations of phenolic acids were 22. and 33. mg/L, respectively, in worts and beers produced in Italy. These amounts represent 5 and 10% of the non-tannic, non-flavonoid phenols in wort and beer, respectively.

Coloring foods with extracts derived from black carrots is considered advantageous not only because of the good pigment stability but also for nutritional reasons. However, most investigations have used crude carrot root extracts or black carrot juice concentrates and have not considered other carrot constituents with antioxidant potential, especially hydroxycinnamic acids, which occur in high amounts. In some studies, antioxidant activity has been correlated with total phenolic content, whereas in others it has been related to total anthocyanin levels. Only a few reports have examined how individual compounds contribute to color properties such as visual detection thresholds and color tone. Cereal antioxidants are largely localized in the bran layer, although the endosperm also contributes to overall antioxidant activity. Because standard extraction procedures fail to efficiently solubilize bound or insoluble phenolics from whole grains, many studies reporting total phenolic content (TPC) in whole grains and bran have only quantified free and esterified phenolics, leading to underestimation of the true TPC. Adom and Liu quantified free and bound phenolics in whole grains and found that bound phenolics made up 90% of the TPC in wheat, 87% in corn, 71% in rice, and 58% in oat. In the present study on wheat, bound phenolics accounted for approximately 40% of the TPC in wheat flour, 60% in wheat whole grain, and 80% in wheat bran. Across all wheat fractions, free phenolics represented 5–20% of the TPC, whereas esterified phenolics contributed 10–30% of the TPC.

Similar to earlier reports, soy foods showed a characteristic total isoflavone pattern. In soy foods, we found a total isoflavone ratio of 45:45:10 for daidzein/genistein/glycitein, corresponding to 45% of total isoflavones as daidzein, 45% as genistein, and 10% as glycitein. Conjugation patterns were more variable. Glucosyl malonates were the predominant conjugate, and in unprocessed soybean and seeds (frozen) as well as in soy flours, glucosyl malonates accounted for 65-72% of total isoflavones. Boiling soybeans for 1 h changed the composition in boiled soybeans (1 h), with a -8% change in glucosyl malonates, a +6% change in glucosides, and +1% changes in acetyl-glucosides and aglycons (% change vs raw). Tau pok (fried pressed tofu) showed the highest contribution of acetyl-glucosides among the foods examined, with acetyl-glucosides making up 24% of total isoflavones in tau pok (fried pressed tofu).

HPLC Analysis of Ellagitannins. Sample extracts (3 mL) were dried using a Speed Vac concentrator (ThermoSavant, Holbrook, NY) and resuspended in 0. mL of extraction solvent. The reconstituted samples were passed through $0. \,\mu m$ PTFE syringe filters (Varian, Inc., Palo Alto, CA) prior to HPLC analysis. The ellagitannins were analyzed on a Waters Alliance HPLC system (Milford, MA) equipped with a Waters model 996 photodiode array detector and Millenium version 3. software (Waters Corp., Milford, MA). Separation was performed using a Phenomenex Aqua 5 $\mu$ m C<sub>18</sub> (250 × 4. mm) column (Torrance, CA) with a binary gradient of 2% acetic acid for mobile phase A and 0.5% acetic acid in water/acetonitrile (1:1 v/v) for mobile phase B at a flow rate of 1. mL/min. A linear gradient was run from 10 to 55% B (0-50 min), from 55 to 100% B (50–60 min), and from 100 to 10% B (60–65 min). The ellagitannins were identified on the basis of comparison of HPLC retention times to our previous HPLC results obtained using the same cultivar, identical HPLC conditions, and LC-MS analysis (4). The ellagitannin peaks were quantified as ellagic acid (EA) equivalents using external calibration curves of ellagic acid, with results expressed as milligram EA equivalents per 100 g of fresh berry weight.

An HPLC–electrospray ionisation–MS–MS offering a high selectivity of detection for a wide range of phenolic compounds and short run times was developed (Ito et al. 2005). In brief, urine samples (250ml) were supplemented with an internal standard (taxifolin), and incubated with deconjugating enzymes to hydrolyse glucuronides and sulphate esters. The freed aglycones were extracted with ethyl acetate. The organic extracts were redissolved in 25 % aqueous methanol and injected into the HPLC–ESI –MS–MS system using a short Zorbax Eclipse XDB-C18 (2·1 i.d. £ 30 mm, 3·5 mm; Agilent Palo Alto, US) and an API-2000 (Applied Biosystems, Ontario, Canada) mass spectrometer. A 4 min gradient of water– formic acid (100:0·1) and acetonitrile –water– formic acid (95:5:0·1) was applied. The whole cycle, including elution and re-equilibration of the column, did not exceed 6 min per sample. Mass detection was carried out with negative ionisation in multiple reaction monitoring mode. Calibration curves were prepared by spiking blank urine with aliquots of standard mixture solutions with duplicated injections at each concentration level.

Within the Mediterranean dietary pattern, vegetables constitute the principal contributors of phenolic compounds, with flavonoids highlighted as particularly important bioactive constituents linked to health benefits. This study examined twenty-seven vegetables, fifteen culinary herbs and selected spices commonly consumed in the Marches region of Central Italy, quantifying total phenolics, flavonoids and flavanols together with antioxidant capacity assessed by the ORAC (oxygen radical absorbance capacity) method. Antioxidant capacities of various salads were compared, including versions to which aromatic herbs had been added. Incorporation of lemon balm or marjoram at 1. % w/w raised the antioxidant capacity of a salad portion by 150 % and 200 %, respectively. A 200 g portion of salad enriched with marjoram provided approximately 200 (sd 10) mg phenolics and 4000 (sd 300) ORAC units (µmol Trolox equivalents). Among the dressings evaluated, olive oils and wine or apple vinegars produced the largest enhancement of antioxidant capacity, whereas cumin and fresh ginger were the spices showing the strongest effects. These findings help to map antioxidant-related parameters of regional vegetables, herbs and spices and to quantify typical intakes of phenolics and ORAC units, offering a basis for public health strategies promoting vegetable consumption for chronic disease prevention.

Text:
The findings of more extensive degradation of strawberry anthocyanins during storage at high temperature are in accordance with results reported previously (20, 37). After 8 weeks at 6 °C, total anthocyanin content was between 73 and 84% of the content in the purees at production. After 16 weeks, the content had decreased to 56-64% of the initial values. After storage at room temperature for 8 and 16 weeks, total anthocyanin contents in the purees were 13-24 and 5-11% of the initial values, respectively. A higher retention of total anthocyanins was observed in strawberry jam stored at 20 °C for 9. weeks (33-47%), whereas retention (6-9%) similar to that in the purees in the present study was observed after about 17 weeks of storage (37). The decay of pelargonidin-3-glucoside, the main anthocyanin in strawberry purees (initially 78%), was similar to that of total anthocyanins. Pelargonidin-3-malonylglucoside was the least stable among the anthocyanins in the strawberry purees. Under storage at 22 °C, only 9-16 and 3-5% of the pelargonidin-3-malonylglucoside were left after 8 and 16 weeks, respectively. Significant demalonation has also previously been observed for malonyl esters of flavonoid glycosides (38). It is worth noting that the amount of 5-carboxypyranopelargonidin-3-glucoside, present in minor amounts in strawberry puree at production (averaging 0.6% of total anthocyanins), increased in purees made from berry homogenate and achene-enriched fraction during storage and contributed 3-4 and 7-10% of total anthocyanins in strawberry purees stored at 22 °C in 8 and 16 weeks, respectively. The higher stability of the pyrano form may be explained by the restricted formation of the unstable, colorless equilibrium forms reported for ordinary anthocyanins (31). The degradation of anthocyanins was lower in purees with higher achene levels. When initially more anthocyanins were present in purees made from flesh, this relationship changed during storage. The increased stability observed when the purees contained more achenes could be caused by stabilization of compounds originating from the achenes, probably ellagic acid-containing compounds, or could be due to the lower content of ascorbic acid, known to accelerate anthocyanin decay (39, 40).

Text:
Processing and storage can substantially modify phenolic composition in berry fruits (10, 14, 15). Freezing strawberries and raspberries led to a 20% reduction in total ellagic acid (measured after acid hydrolysis of ellagitannins), and a further 9 months of frozen storage caused up to an additional 40% degradation of ellagic acid. In contrast, strawberry jams stored for 9 months showed no detectable losses in total ellagic acid (15). Given that native ellagitannins may undergo degradation or depolymerization, assessing how processing affects ellagitannin content and composition is important for understanding potential health effects. This study therefore investigated the impact of processing and storage on ellagitannins in IQF berries and in blackberry products such as juices, canned-in-syrup (CS), canned-in-water (CW), and purees.

Since the amount of seeds was mostly limited, carrot yields were generally poor. Therefore, representative samples of all carrots, which were harvested at the same time, were investigated for their anthocyanin contents. For PI 176970 (Turkey, Konya), PI 179690 (India, Gujarat) and 005833 (Johns Purple Carrot) two sub-samples were analyzed, demonstrating large heterogeneity of the anthocyanin contents within the cultivars. Since local plant material (black carrot, Germany) was abundant, roots were harvested at four different sites of the experimental plots at different stages, beginning at the end of August and ending mid-October, thus allowing the evaluation of the infra-specific variability of anthocyanin accumulation as well as of the influence of harvest date on pigment concentration of the roots. The total anthocyanin contents depending on harvest time are presented in Fig. 3. Most obviously, pigment contents within the same cultivar are subject to great variation, especially for the second, third and fourth harvest date. In general, maximal total anthocyanin contents were observed between mid-September and October. The pigment pattern showed only minor differences throughout this period. The average proportion of acylated compounds ranged from 80. (end of August) to 84.8% (mid-October), without showing significant differences. The same observations were made for the proportion of the predominant compound cyanidin feruloylxylosylglucosylgalactoside.

To discuss the anthocyanin excretion in rats, the urine and bile were collected after intravenous administration of Bilberon 25. The recoveries of anthocyanin in urine and bile were only 30. and 13.4%, respectively. Similar values were obtained previously when purified cyanidin 3-O-â-D-glucoside was intravenously given to rats (35). Because the total recovery of intravenously administered anthocyanins in urine and bile was approximately 45% during the first 4 h, it was suggested that considerable decomposition and/or tissue accumulation of anthocyanins occurred. The anthocyanin profiles in urine and bile were completely different from those of original Bilberon 25 indicating that anthocyanins were metabolized in tissues such as liver and kidneys (Figure 6). Biphasic decay of plasma anthocyanins after intravenous administration supports the possibility of anthocyanin distribution in tissues (Figure 5).

Text:
Most antioxidant compounds in cereals are associated with the bran fraction, although the endosperm still exhibits notable antioxidant activity. Because routine extraction protocols do not efficiently release bound or insoluble phenolics from whole grains, many reported total phenolic content (TPC) values for whole grains and bran, which typically include only free and esterified phenolics, underestimate the true TPC. Adom and Liu showed that in whole grains of wheat, corn, rice, and oat, bound phenolics represented 90, 87, 71, and 58% of the TPC, respectively. In our own work focused on wheat, bound phenolics contributed about 40% of the TPC in wheat flour, around 60% in wheat whole grain, and roughly 80% in wheat bran. For the wheat fractions as a group, free phenolics accounted for 5–20% of the TPC, while esterified phenolics contributed 10–30% of the TPC.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Linear furanocoumarins (LFCs) were identified in the late 1940s as the cause of the photosensitization properties of the plants that contain them (Fahmy et al., 1947; Fahmy and Abu-Shady, 1948). LFCs are found in a wide variety of plants in the Apiaceae, Rutaeae, and Moraceae (Gray and Waterman, 1978; Berenbaum, 1981; Murray et al., 1982; Matern et al., 1988; Zobel and Brown, 1990). The biological importance and activities of these compounds have been reviewed (Beier and Nigg, 1992). Briefly, LFCs are known to intercalate into DNA and form covalent bonds in the presence of UVA light (320–400 nm). Psoralens have been used to determine the structure and function of DNAs and RNAs because of their reactivity with these compounds (Cimino et al., 1985). LFCs have been used clinically to treat skin disorders such as vitiligo and prurigo nodularis and have been proposed as a treatment for jet lag. About 40 mg of psoralen administered orally, combined with UVA light, is referred to as PUVA therapy. PUVA therapy has caused papillomas, keratoanthomas, and squamous cell carcinomas in mice and has been linked to genital cancer in men (Beier and Nigg, 1992).

Text:
To clarify how structural diversity of anthocyanins relates to their in vivo function, bioavailability was precisely studied in rats using bilberry (Vaccinium myrtillus L.) extract (Bilberon 25) as an anthocyanin source that contains 15 different anthocyanins. The bilberry extract was orally or intravenously administered to rats, and the plasma levels of each anthocyanin were determined by high-performance liquid chromatography. As the result, all anthocyanins except peonidin 3-O-α-L-arabinoside were detectable in the blood plasma. The plasma concentration of anthocyanins as a whole reached the maximum level of 1. $\mu$ M at 15 min after oral administration of 400 mg/kg bilberry extract (153. mg/kg as anthocyanins) and then decreased with time. Uptake and decay profiles of each anthocyanin in the plasma were almost the same for all anthocyanins except a few with their maximum after 30 min. Among the anthocyanins carrying the same aglycone, the plasma level after 15 min of oral administration was as follows: galactoside > glucoside > arabinoside. Plasma clearance of anthocyanins after intravenous administration clearly showed that arabinoside disappeared more rapidly than glucoside and galactoside. On the other hand, when anthocyanins carrying the same sugar moiety were compared, the half disappearance time of plasma anthocyanins was in the following order: delphinidin > cyanidin > petunidin = peonidin > malvidin. The bioavailability of anthocyanins was in the range of 0.61-1.82% and was 0.93% as the anthocyanin mixture. The bioavailability of anthocyanins carrying the same aglycone was in the following order: Galactoside showed the highest followed by glucoside and arabinoside for cyanidin and delphinidin, but arabinoside and galactoside showed a higher bioavailability than glucoside for petunidin and malvidin. Anthocyanins recovered in urine and bile during the first 4 h after intravenous administration were only 30. and 13.4%, respectively. Anthocyanin profiles in tissues were quite different from those in blood plasma. The major anthocyanins distributed in liver and kidney were the O-methyl anthocyanins such as peonidin, malvidin, and other O-methyl anthocyanins derived from delphinidin, cyanidin, and petunidin-glycosides.

(2001), and MX4 (2001)] . On the other hand, predictions made in peel for some varieties differed from the results obtained in pulp. In this sense, MX2 (2000) and PT (2000) classified as bitter in pulp were predicted as nonbitter in peel, whereas GG (2001) and MX11 (2001), nonbitter in pulp, were classified as bitter in peel. An explanation of this observation could be the fact that apple peel composition depends to a great extent on climatology (6) and sun exposure of the fruit, existing differences according to the position of the fruit in the tree and even, in the same fruit, between sun-exposed parts and shaded parts (25). Considering the peel and pulp distribution of polyphenols in the different apple cultivars studied, it was confirmed that the synthesis and accumulation of phenolic compounds are specific to each kind of apple tissue (peel, pulp), which had been previously reported (25, 26). Taking into account the objective of this study, and as a result of the observations made, pulp predictions were considered as more reliable than those in peel, because they were more homogeneous and did not depend so much on external factors. However, it is important to note that for 80% of the samples, bitterness predictions are concordant in pulp and peel, which allows the conclusion that apple tissues present characteristic compositions that permit them to be distinguished from a technological point of view.

Ellagitannin Content of Canned Berries and Cover Liquid. By evaluating the content of ellagitannins in the berries and liquid canning medium fractions separately (expressed as mg in the whole can) throughout storage, we were able to quantify the amount of ellagitannins that leached out of the berries into the liquid canning media during storage . The ellagitannin content of CS berries decreased dramatically throughout 6 months of storage (42% loss in total ellagitannins), whereas the total ellagitannin content of the CS liquid fraction increased 2. fold from 1 day to 6 months of storage. In contrast, there was no change in the CW berry total ellagitannin content with storage due to large variations in total content, but the total ellagitannin content of the CW liquid fraction increased 2.0-fold from 1 day to 6 months of storage, indicating leaching still occurred. Individual ellagitannins behaved similarly throughout storage in all samples. The loss of liquid due to draining of canned products by consumers may be a source of losses in ellagitannins, but even with increased ellagitannin content of the liquid fractions over 6 months of storage, there were still only 10-20% of the total ellagitannins present in the liquid fractions. The remaining 80-90% of total ellagitannins was retained in the berries; therefore, the effects of draining the product would be minimal and may not reduce potential health benefits from ellagitannins.

Text:
Antioxidant Activity. L’attività antiossidante degli alimenti derivante dall’insieme dei composti idrofili e lipofili è stata studiata solo raramente; la maggior parte dei lavori si limita a misurare la frazione idrosolubile, nonostante il ruolo protettivo dimostrato di alcuni costituenti lipidici nei confronti di malattie da stress ossidativo (7, 33). Le informazioni disponibili sull’effetto dei processi tecnologici sono limitate, ma dati USDA relativi a circa 100 alimenti indicano che la cottura può tanto aumentare quanto ridurre l’attività antiossidante, in funzione della natura e della struttura degli antiossidanti (33). Nella filiera di trasformazione del mais in masa, tortillas e tortilla chips, la serie di trattamenti termici modifica sensibilmente la capacità antiossidante. La frittura profonda utilizzata per produrre i tortilla chips è il passaggio più critico: il prodotto finale conserva meno della metà della capacità antiossidante del grano crudo. Al contrario, la semplice cottura della masa in tortillas comporta un lieve incremento dell’attività antiossidante, verosimilmente dovuto all’aumento di fenoli solubili liberati dalla matrice.

As compared to soaking treatment, cooking processing caused a significant increase in ORAC value (42%). Xu and Chang (36) reported similar behavior in cooked chickpeas and lentils; however the contrary was observed in cooked black beans (40). There was no significant difference between cooked and dehydrated lentil flours. Thus, the changes of ORAC values could be attributed to the leaching of phenolic compounds into the soaking and cooking water. However, other phenomena such as better solubility of antioxidant nonphenolic compounds following thermal treatment and the formation of Maillard products with increased free radical scavenging properties may be involved (41).

Text:
Effect of Thermal Processing on Anthocyanin Composition. The anthocyanin contents of the original raw and cooked pinto and black beans are presented in Table 3. Anthocyanins were not detectable in the raw and cooked pinto beans. Five anthocyanins, namely, delphinidin-3-glucoside, malvidin-3,5-diglucoside, petunidin-3-glucoside, malvidin-3-galactoside, and malvidin-3-glucoside, were detected in the raw black beans. The dominant components were delphinidin-3-glucoside, malvidin-3,5-diglucoside, petunidin-3-glucoside, and malvidin-3-glucoside. These findings are in accordance with those of Takeoka et al. (5 ) and Wu and Prior (35 ), who found that delphinidin-3-glucoside, petunidin-3-glucoside, and malvidin-3-glucoside were the major anthocyanins in black common beans. The discrepancy was that malvidin-3,5-diglucoside as the third major component after delphinidin-3-glucoside and petunidin-3-glucoside was detected in our pinto bean sample at a higher content than malvidin-3 glucoside. However, malvidin-3,5-diglucoside was reported as the minor anthocyanin in black beans in previous studies (5, 35). The reason may partly be due to the age of the beans (harvested in 2004 and analyzed in 2007), in which a glycosylation process might occur during postharvest storage.

Text:
Chlorogenic acids occur in particularly high concentrations in coffee and are partly transformed into chlorogenic acid lactones (CGL) when the beans are roasted. In a set of experiments with Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon, Coffea arabica cv. Longberry, and Coffea canephora cv. Robusta, we quantified individual CGL by HPLC using synthetic standards. At a light medium roast level (~14 % weight loss), 3-caffeoylquinic-1,5-lactone (3-CQL) was the dominant lactone in both species, with Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon reaching 230 ± 9 mg/100 g dry weight and Coffea canephora cv. Robusta reaching 254 mg/100 g dry weight. The second most abundant lactone was 4-caffeoylquinic-1,5-lactone (4-CQL), which attained 116 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon and 139 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea canephora cv. Robusta. At this roast degree, the sum of all chlorogenic acid lactones formed accounts for about 30 % of the available chlorogenic acid precursors.

The decline in ellagitannins during storage was dependent upon achene level; that is, a faster decline was observed when more achenes, and also more ellagitannins, were present . The concentrations of ellagitannins in purees made from flesh did not change during storage. In purees made from berry homogenate and achene-enriched fraction, 80 and 72% of the initial ellagitannins remained in the purees after 16 weeks at 22 °C, respectively. After 16 weeks at 6 and 22 °C, 75-89 and 57-61% of the ellagic acid glycosides present in the purees at production remained, respectively. The concentration of ellagic acid in the purees increased steadily during storage and was nearly doubled after 16 weeks at 22 °C. Yet, the level of ellagic acid might be underestimated because of the low solubility of free ellagic acid. The increase in free ellagic acid may be explained by release of ellagic acid after hydrolysis of the ellagitannins. In raspberry jam, free ellagic acid was almost doubled after the first month of storage at 20 °C and then the concentration decreased during the next 3 months (16). In strawberry jam, total ellagic acid content did not change during storage for 9 months at -20 °C or at 5 °C (17). In the present study, the only significant decrease in content of combined ellagic acid-containing compounds during storage was observed in purees made from achene-enriched fraction stored for 16 weeks at 22 °C.

Changes in blackberry ellagitannin composition in response to juicing (clarified and nonclarified), pureeing, canning (in water or syrup), and freezing as well as changes in processed products during 6 months of storage were investigated. Canning, pureeing, and freezing had little effect on ellagitannins, but processing berries into nonclarified and clarified juices resulted in total ellagitannin losses of 70 and 82%, respectively, due to removal of ellagitannin-rich seeds in the presscake. Minimal changes in total ellagitannin content were observed during storage of thermally processed products, but compositional changes indicative of ellagitannin depolymerization were apparent. The ellagitannin content and composition of frozen berries remained stable over 6 months of storage. Ellagitannins are well retained in canned, pureed, and frozen blackberries, but methods are needed to prevent losses during juice processing and/or exploit the ellagitannin-rich coproducts.

Determination of TPC. The content of total phenolics was determined according to a modified version of the procedure described by Singleton and Rossi (27). Folin-Ciocalteu's reagent (0. mL) was added to a centrifuge tube (50 mL) containing 0. mL of the methanolic extract. Contents were mixed, and 1 mL of saturated sodium carbonate solution was added to each tube, followed by adjustment of the volume to 10 mL with distilled water. The contents in the tubes were thoroughly mixed by vortexing. Tubes were allowed to stand at ambient temperature for 45 min until the characteristic blue color developed; centrifugation was then carried out for 5 min at 4000g (ICE Centra M5, International Equipment Co., Needham Heights, MA). Absorbance of the clear supernatants was measured at 725 nm using a Hewlett-Packard diode array spectrophotometer, model 8452A (Agilent Technologies Canada Inc., Mississauga, ON). The content of total phenolics in each extract was determined by explaining a standard curve prepared using ferulic acid and expressed as micrograms of ferulic acid equivalents (FAE) per gram of defatted material.

Catechins and proanthocyanidins constituted the major phenolic fraction in raw pardina lentils, accounting for 69% of the identified phenolics, with a total level of 74. µg/g. Within this group, (+)-catechin 3-glucoside was the predominant compound (39. µg/g), followed by a procyanidin trimer and procyanidin B2. These observations are consistent with previous reports by Escarpa and González (27), Amarowicz and Karamac (28), and Martín-Cabrejas et al. (7). In contrast to Dueñas et al. (24), prodelphinidins were not detected in raw lentils. Industrial dehydration caused marked decreases in these phenolics: (+)-catechin 3-glucoside showed the strongest reduction (95%), and most procyanidins were no longer detectable at the end of processing. The applied thermal treatments (cooking and dehydration) likely promote degradation of more polymerized proanthocyanidins, hydrolysis of glycosylated flavonoids, and breakdown of aglycones (10, 29). Air-drying at temperatures above 60 °C is generally considered detrimental for efficient extraction of phenolic compounds because of oxidative condensation and decomposition of thermolabile molecules such as (+)-catechins (32).

Chromatographic analyses were performed on a Hewlett-Packard series 1100 system, equipped with a vacuum degasser, a quaternary pump, a thermostated autosampler, a thermostated column compartment, and a DAD, connected to HP ChemStation software. A reversed-phase Nova-Pak C18 ( $300 \times 3. \text{ mm}$ i.d., $4 \mu\text{m}$ ) column and a Nova-Pak C18 ( $10 \times 3. \text{ mm}$ i.d., $4 \mu\text{m}$ ) guard column (Waters, Barcelona, Spain) were used. Solvents that constituted the mobile phase were acetic acid/water, 10:90, v/v (A), and methanol (B). The elution conditions applied were as follows: 0–10 min, 0% B isocratic; 10–40 min, linear gradient from 0 to 15% B; 40–60 min, 15% B isocratic; and finally, washing and reconditioning of the column. The flow rate was $0. \text{ mL min}^{-1}$ , and the injection volume was $50 \mu\text{L}$ for the crude extracts or $10 \mu\text{L}$ for the thiolysis media. The chromatographic separation was carried out at $25 ^\circ\text{C}$ . Catechins and dihydrochalcones were monitored and quantified at $280 \text{ nm}$ , hydroxycinnamic acids at $320 \text{ nm}$ , flavonols at $370 \text{ nm}$ , and anthocyanins at $530 \text{ nm}$ . Polyphenol identification was achieved by comparison of their retention times and their UV-visible spectra with those of the standards that were available. Some other chromatographic peaks were assigned to a particular polyphenol class according to their UV-visible spectra and bibliographic sources. In this sense, those unknown chromatographic peaks that exhibit flavan-3-ol spectra were appointed as CAT-n, and those with a spectrum of 5-caffeoylquinic acid as CAA-n, of p-coumaric as CMA-n, of dihydrochalcone as PLD-n, of flavonol as QG-n and of anthocyanin as CG-n (where n is a number). Quantification was performed by reporting the measured integration areas in the calibration equation of the corresponding standards. Thus, procyanidin B2 and the unknown flavan-3-ols were quantified as (+)-catechin, phloretin 2'-O-xyloglucoside and the unknown dihydrochalcones as phloridzin, avicularin and the unknown flavonols as rutin, CAA-n species as 5-caffeoylquinic acid, 4-p-coumaroylquinic acid and CMA-n species as p-coumaric acid, and the unknown anthocyanins as ideain.
NONE

In this supplementation experiment (intake of 1 litre of pomegranate juice daily for 5 days), every volunteer ingested a total of 24. g ellagic acid equivalents (as punicalagin, ellagic acid and ellagic acid glycosides). A large variability in the transformation of ellagic acid metabolites in the corresponding hydroxy-6H-dibenzopyran-6 one derivatives was observed in the healthy volunteers. One of them metabolised and excreted in urine more than 50 % of the ingested ellagic acid, while others excreted below 1 % of the ingested ellagic acid as this type of compound or any other compounds that could be detected in the HPLC analysis either with DAD-UV or MS-MS detection . Regarding the urinary excretion kinetics, the metabolites were detected in urine after 24h of the first pomegranate juice intake to reach a maximum excretion between day 3 and 4 (results not shown).

Text:
Thermal processing had a marked effect on anthocyanin retention in black beans, following patterns similar to those previously reported for black soybeans (24 ). All tested thermal-processing treatments significantly (p < 0.05) lowered the levels of each individual anthocyanin. Among the different methods, regular steaming preserved higher amounts of delphinidin-3-glucoside, malvidin-3,5-diglucoside, and petunidin-3-glucoside, whereas pressure steaming removed essentially all malvidin-3-glucoside and malvidin-3-galactoside. In pressure-steamed black beans, only trace levels of delphindin-3-glucoside (22. μg/g), petunidin-3-glucoside (11. μg/g), and malvidin-3-glucoside (6. μg/g) were detected. No significant differences in total anthocyanin contents were observed between regularly boiled and pressure-boiled black beans. Relative to raw black beans, overall thermal processing resulted in losses of 93.3-99% for delphinidin-3 glucoside, 58.8-100% for malvidin-3,5-diglucoside, 91.5-98.7% for petunidin-3-glucoside, 100% for malvidin-3-galactoside, and 88.2-98.5% for malvidin-3-glucoside, confirming extensive degradation of anthocyanin profiles during processing.

Light–medium roasting of Coffea arabica generates small but measurable amounts of p-coumaroyl-1,5-lactones (pCoQL) from p-coumaroylquinic acids. After 7 min roast, Bourbon coffee showed 7 mg/100 g of 3-pCoQL and an identical level (7 mg/100 g) of 4-pCoQL. In contrast, Longberry coffee contained only 4 mg/100 g of 3-pCoQL and 2 mg/100 g of 4-pCoQL. These values highlight cultivar-dependent differences in the formation of 3- and 4-pCoQL while confirming that both remain minor phenolic lactones in roasted coffee.

Black carrot–based colorants have been proposed as promising ingredients because they combine good pigment stability with potential nutritional value. Yet, many studies have evaluated crude carrot root extracts or concentrates of black carrot juice without accounting for additional antioxidant constituents, notably the hydroxycinnamic acids that occur at high levels. Antioxidant activity has sometimes been correlated with total phenolics and in other cases with total anthocyanin content, and only a few investigations have addressed the role of individual compounds in determining color attributes such as detection thresholds and tonality. Despite the recognized benefits of black carrots as natural colorant sources, there is still no information regarding the concentrations of specific anthocyanins in the roots. Reported total anthocyanin contents, obtained by spectrophotometric methods, range between 1 and 98 mg/100 g fresh weight.

The occurrence of p-coumaroyl-1,5-lactones (pCoQL) in roasted coffee has rarely been quantified, largely because they are present at very low levels. Their precursors, p-coumaroylquinic acids (pCoQA), are minor chlorogenic acids in both green and roasted coffee, typically around 30–70 mg/100 g in green arabica and 50–60 mg/100 g in Robusta. After 7 min of roasting, Bourbon coffee contained about 7 mg/100 g of 3-pCoQL, whereas Longberry contained 4 mg/100 g. For 4-pCoQL, the corresponding values were 7 mg/100 g in Bourbon and 2 mg/100 g in Longberry. These data illustrate that pCoQL are minor but detectable lactone products in light–medium roasted Coffea arabica.

Effect of Processing. The effects of shredding and subsequent exposure to light on both the level and composition of the flavonoids in the eight varieties of lettuce are shown in Table 4. Significant losses in the total flavonol content were found for the green and red oak leaf (94 and 43%, respectively), iceberg (36%), green batavia (25%), and lollo biondo and rosso varieties (24 and 6%, respectively). The large loss of flavonoid (94%) observed for green oak leaf corresponded to a visible amount of tissue degradation, which was not seen in the other varieties. Significant losses of the malonated forms of both quercetin glucoside and cyanidin glucoside were not matched on a quantitative basis by a corresponding increase in the glucoside, and these losses did not result in the formation of the respective aglycons.

Antioxidant Activity. Figures 1 and 2 show the hydrophilic and lipophilic antioxidant activities of free and bound phenolics of the raw corns and their nixtamalized products as micromoles of vitamin C or E per 100 g of sample, respectively. It was clear that bound phenolics were the primary contributors of antioxidant activity, consistent with the previous observations for total phenolics and ferulic acid content (5-7). The hydrophilic antioxidant activity of free phenolics significantly increased (p > 0.05) after nixtamalization. The range of antioxidant activity for raw grains was from 41. ± 2. to 49. ± 4. μmol of vitamin C equiv/100 g. High-carotenoid corn contained the highest antioxidant capacity. The values for masa, tortillas, and chips varied from 68. to 114. μmol of vitamin C/100 g. The hydrophilic antioxidant activity in the bound form, however, decreased after lime-cooking. The activity decreased approximately 30% in masa and more than 50% in tortilla chips, when compared to raw corn. The hydrophilic antioxidant activity represented ~98% of the total antioxidant activity. The free lipophilic antioxidant activity also increased when products were lime-cooked and processed into tortillas and tortilla chips.

Neochlorogenic acid was identified as the main hydroxycinnamic acid in sweet cherries. In ripe fruits its concentration spanned 22–190 mg/100 g of fw, representing between 19 and 71% of total phenolics, while in partially ripe fruits it was 19–126 mg/100 g of fw and contributed 24–72%. The levels of p-coumaroylquinic and chlorogenic acids did not change markedly with ripening or storage within a given cultivar. For p-coumaroylquinic acid, values of 4–34 mg/100 g of fw were reported, equivalent to 4% of total phenolics in cv. Van and 27% in cv. Summit. Chlorogenic acid ranged from 3 to 12 mg/100 g of fw, accounting for 2% of phenolics in cv. Van and 4% in cv. Saco. All other hydroxycinnamic acids together represented less than 2% of the total phenolic content.

Flavan-3-ols and Flavonols Content. Per ciascuna cultivar di ciliegio sono stati determinati i livelli di catechina, epicatechina e del flavonolo rutin (Tabella 5). Il contenuto di flavonoli variava in modo netto tra le cultivar (P < 0.001), mentre le differenze tra i diversi anni di raccolta non risultavano significative. La cv. Saco mostrava il contenuto più elevato di rutin (14 mg/100 g di peso fresco), mentre le cvs. Burlat e Summit presentavano solo 3 mg/100 g di fw, valori che rappresentavano circa il 5% e il 3% del contenuto totale di fenoli, rispettivamente. Il livello di rutin tendeva ad aumentare con l’avanzare della maturazione: nel caso di Saco, nel 2002, si osservava un passaggio da 3 a 10 mg/100 g di fw, ovvero un incremento di circa tre volte, dallo stadio parzialmente maturo a quello maturo. Nel periodo di conservazione, il contenuto di flavonoli nelle ciliegie, indipendentemente dallo stadio di maturazione iniziale e dalla temperatura di stoccaggio, rimaneva sostanzialmente invariato.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Detection was performed with a UV diode array detector by scanning from 210 to 360 nm. Identification of phenolic compounds was carried out by comparing retention times and spectral data with those of authentic standards. Identified phenolic compounds were quantified using the external standard method, and quantification was based on peak area. Calibration curves of the standards were made by diluting stock standards in methanol to yield 2–30 mg L $^{-1}$ (syringic and ferulic acid), 5–50 mg L $^{-1}$ (chlorogenic acid and catechins), 5–30 mg L $^{-1}$ (caffeic and p-coumaric acid), and 2–20 mg L $^{-1}$ rutin. Procyanidin B $2$ and kaempferol 3-rutinoside were identified only by polarity and spectral data from the literature, and they were not determined quantitatively except for kaempferol 3-rutinoside, which was quantified as quercetin 3-rutinoside. The samples were prepared and analyzed in triplicate. Data presented are mean $\pm$ standard deviation (SD).

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
The study examined how juicing (clarified and nonclarified), pureeing, canning (in water or syrup), and freezing affect blackberry ellagitannins, and how these processed products change over 6 months of storage. Canning, pureeing, and freezing caused only minor changes in ellagitannin levels, whereas converting berries into nonclarified and clarified juices led to substantial total ellagitannin losses of 70 and 82 %, respectively, mainly because ellagitannin-rich seeds were removed in the presscake. During storage of thermally processed products, total ellagitannin content remained fairly constant, although compositional shifts suggested ellagitannin depolymerization. In contrast, frozen berries retained both ellagitannin content and composition over 6 months. Overall, ellagitannins are largely preserved in canned, pureed, and frozen blackberries, but juice processing still causes major losses unless coproducts are utilized.

(20) and modified in our laboratory (8). Briefly, the appropriate dilutions of extracts were oxidized with the Folin-Ciocalteu reagent, and the reaction was neutralized with sodium carbonate. Blackberry ellagitannins were monitored after different processing steps (juicing, pureeing, canning, freezing) and during 6 months of storage. Processes such as canning, pureeing, and freezing produced only minor changes in total ellagitannin levels, but converting berries into juice led to pronounced losses. In particular, nonclarified blackberry juice showed a 70 % reduction in total ellagitannins, and clarified juice showed an even higher loss of 82 %, largely because ellagitannin-rich seeds were retained in the presscake instead of the juice. Thermally processed products showed little change in total ellagitannin content during storage, whereas frozen berries maintained both content and composition throughout the 6-month period.

During the intervention, volunteers ingested 1 litre of pomegranate juice daily over a period of 5 days, giving a cumulative dose of 24 g of ellagic acid equivalents derived from punicalagin, ellagic acid, and ellagic acid glycosides. Marked differences among individuals were observed in the biotransformation of ellagic acid into hydroxy-6H-dibenzopyran-6-one metabolites. One subject excreted more than 50% of the administered ellagic acid in urine, whereas several others excreted less than 1%, with no additional metabolites detectable by HPLC using DAD-UV or MS-MS. Urinary metabolites were first detectable 24 h after the initial juice intake and reached maximal excretion between the third and fourth day.

Our observations are consistent with previous reports (12), which indicated that most thermal treatments, with the exception of microwave heating, reduced anthocyanin levels in various vegetables by roughly 24–35%, close to the 30% decrease measured in our study (Table 2). Comparable patterns were described for other processing methods: steamed vegetables retained around 80% of their phenolic content (2), whereas boiled vegetables preserved only about 30% of their antioxidant activity. In onions, boiling results in an approximate 30% loss of quercetin glycosides (37), mainly due to their diffusion into the cooking water, while frying does not appear to substantially alter flavonoid intake (Tables 2 and 3).

Text:
In the Mediterranean diet, vegetables represent the main dietary source of phenolic compounds. These phenolics, particularly flavonoids, are regarded as key bioactive molecules associated with health-promoting effects. In this work, twenty-seven vegetables, fifteen aromatic herbs and several spices commonly eaten in Central Italy (Marches region) were analyzed for total phenolics, flavonoids, flavanols and their antioxidant capacity using the ORAC (oxygen radical absorbance capacity) assay. Antioxidant capacity was compared among different salads and between plain salads and those supplemented with aromatic herbs. When added at 1. % w/w, lemon balm and marjoram increased the antioxidant capacity of a salad portion by 150 % and 200 %, respectively. A 200 g serving of salad enriched with marjoram supplied about 200 (sd 10) mg phenolics and 4000 (sd 300) ORAC units (µmol Trolox equivalents). Among salad dressings, olive oils and wine or apple vinegars led to the greatest rise in antioxidant capacity, while among spices, cumin and fresh ginger gave the most marked contributions. These data allow characterization of antioxidant parameters of locally produced vegetables, herbs and spices and enable estimation of daily phenolic and ORAC intake, information that may support public health initiatives aimed at increasing consumption of protective vegetables to help prevent chronic disease.

Text:
Antioxidant compounds in cereals are mainly concentrated in the bran fraction, although the endosperm of the grain also shows considerable antioxidant activity. Under normal extraction conditions, bound or insoluble phenolics are unlikely to be fully recovered from whole grains. Several published values for the total phenolic content (TPC) of whole grains and bran have only included free and esterified phenolics, meaning that the true TPC is probably underestimated in many of those studies. Adom and Liu determined free and bound phenolics in whole grains of wheat, corn, rice, and oat, and reported that bound phenolics contributed 90, 87, 71, and 58% to the TPCs of wheat, corn, rice, and oat, respectively. In our study on wheat, bound phenolics contributed approximately 40% of the TPC in wheat flour, 60% in wheat whole grain, and 80% in wheat bran. Across wheat fractions, free phenolics accounted for about 5–20% of the TPC, whereas esterified phenolics contributed roughly 10–30% of the TPC.

Flavan-3-ols, namely catechin and epicatechin, varied significantly across sweet cherry cultivars and between the two years studied (P < 0.001). At harvest, cv. In the context of this work on brassica vegetables, we quantified how steaming and boiling influence phenolics and antioxidant capacity. Steaming allowed the vegetables to retain roughly 80 % of the phenolic content and ORAC values compared with raw samples. Boiling was far more destructive, leaving only about 30 % of the total antioxidants and negatively affecting flavour. Overall, a linear negative relationship emerged between the type/intensity of cooking and phenolic content, moving from raw to boiled. These data clearly point to gentle steaming as the cooking process of choice to preserve phenolics, ORAC-related antioxidant capacity, and vitamins.

The Fe(II) chelation capacity reached 10572 µg EDTA equivalents/g of defatted material. Free phenolics from soft and hard wheats showed poor Fe(II) chelating ability, whereas the chelation behavior of free, esterified, and bound fractions closely followed their total phenolic contents (TPCs). A clear positive relationship was observed between TPC and Fe(II) chelation. After alkaline hydrolysis of wheat samples, phenolic aglycons were released and could effectively contribute to Fe(II) binding. By contrast, when phenolic acids remained in esterified or bound forms, their capacity to chelate Fe(II) appeared to be restricted. In line with previous findings on aqueous radical trapping, glycosylation of phenolic compounds reduced antioxidant activity because the OH group was not available to react, and a similar reduction was apparent for Fe(II) chelation.

Feruloyl-1,5-lactones (FQL). The occurrence of FQL has been previously described in fractions of roasted coffee (26, 27). We identified and quantified two major feruloyl-1,5-lactones, 3-FQL and 4-FQL. The highest amount of these compounds also occurred at 7 min of roasting, and the same pattern observed for CQL was observed for FQL. Although the amount of 4-FQA was higher than the amount of 3-FQA in all three samples, 3-FQL was the major FQL. The maximum levels of 3-FQL for Bourbon and Longberry samples were 29. and 29. mg/100 g, while the maximum levels of 4-FQL were 13. and 11. mg/100 g, respectively. 3-FQL could not be quantified in the Robusta sample due to its coelution with other peak(s). The formation of 3-FQL and 4-FQL mirrored that of CQL, as evidenced by the ratio of 70:30 between 3-FQL and 4-FQL in arabica samples.

Ellagitannin content in canned blackberries and their cover liquids was monitored by measuring berries and canning medium separately (expressed as mg per whole can) over storage. In canned blackberries in syrup (CS), berry ellagitannins dropped sharply during 6 months, with a 42% loss in total ellagitannins, while the CS liquid fraction exhibited a 2.5-fold increase in total ellagitannins between 1 day and 6 months, indicating leaching from the fruit. For canned blackberries in water (CW), total ellagitannins in the berries did not show a clear net change because of variability, but the CW liquid fraction still showed a 2.0-fold increase over the same period. Despite this movement into the liquid, after 6 months only about 10–20% of total ellagitannins were present in the liquid fractions, whereas 80–90% remained in the berries, suggesting that discarding the liquid would cause only limited losses of ellagitannins and likely not greatly impact potential health benefits.

All identified phenolic acids were quantified with external standards using HPLC analysis, as described previously (24). To prepare 1 mg/mL stock solution of the standard mixture, 10 mg of each phenolic acid compound was mixed together and dissolved in 10 mL of 25% methanol. The stock solution was diluted into nine series of standard working solution with distilled water (100, 50, 25, 10, 5, 2.5, 1, 0.5, and 0. μg/mL). Standard curves of phenolic acids were established by plotting peak areas against the concentrations of the standards from the averages of duplicate injections. Text:
Determination of Anthocyanins in Plasma, Urine, and Bile. Sample preparation for HPLC analysis of anthocyanins from biological samples was followed using our previously reported method (34, 35). Briefly, the plasma samples (300 µL) were applied to Sep-Pak C18 cartridges light (Waters) preconditioned with MeOH (3 mL) and 3% TFA aqueous solution (3 mL). Then, the cartridges were washed successively with 3 mL of 3% TFA aqueous solution, dichloromethane, and benzene (3 mL each). Anthocyanins were eluted with 50% acetonitrile containing 1% TFA aqueous solution. The recovered anthocyanins were evaporated to dryness in vacuo at a temperature below 40 °C and dissolved in 150 µL of distilled water containing 0.5% TFA, and then, an aliquot (100 µL) of the solutions was injected into an HPLC system (Hitachi 7200). In the case of intravenous administered plasma samples, further dilution was carried out depending on the color of the samples. Urine and bile samples were prepared as described above using Sep-Pak C18 cartridges Environment (Waters). All of the washing and elution procedures were carried out using 10 mL of the solvent. HPLC was carried out on a Develosil ODS HG-5 column (Nomura Chemical Co. Ltd., Japan, 150 mm × 1. mm) using 18% MeOH containing 0.5% TFA as the elution solvent at a flow rate of 0. mL/min, and the elution peaks were monitored at 520 nm with a UV-visible detector (Hitachi, Japan). The recovery of anthocyanins through the above method was checked using Bilberon 25, and it was determined as 87.5%. A calibration curve for each anthocyanin was made using purified anthocyanidin-glycoside (3-O-glycopyranoside of delphinidin, cyanidin, petunidin, peonidin, and malvidin) as the reference. The anthocyanin metabolites were quantified as cyanidin 3-Oâ-D-glucoside equivalent.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Recent studies indicate that anthocyanin intake conveys a variety of health benefits, which depend on absorption and metabolic mechanisms that deliver anthocyanins and their bioactive metabolites to responsive tissues. The anthocyanin bioavailability of red cabbage (Brassica oleracea L. var. capitata) was evaluated as reflected by urinary excretion of anthocyanins and anthocyanin metabolites. Twelve volunteers consumed 100, 200, and 300 g of steamed red cabbage (containing 1. $\mu$ mol of anthocyanins/g of cabbage) in a crossover design. Anthocyanin concentration in cabbage extract and urine was measured by HPLC-MS/MS. Six nonacylated and 30 acylated anthocyanins were detected in red cabbage, and 3 nonacylated anthocyanins, 8 acylated anthocyanins, and 4 metabolites were present in urine. Mean 24 h excretion of intact anthocyanins increased linearly from 45 (100 g dose) to 65 nmol (300 g dose) for acylated anthocyanins and from 52 (100 g dose) to 79 nmol (300 g dose) for nonacylated anthocyanins. Urinary recovery of intact anthocyanins (percent of anthocyanin intake) decreased linearly from 0.041% (100 g dose) to 0.020% (300 g dose) for acylated anthocyanins and from 0.18% (100 g dose) to 0.09% (300 g dose) for nonacylated anthocyanins. Anthocyanin metabolites consisted of glucuronidated and methylated anthocyanins. The results show that red cabbage anthocyanins were excreted in both intact and metabolized forms and that recovery of nonacylated anthocyanins in urine was >4-fold that of acylated anthocyanins.

Feruloyl-1,5-lactones (FQL) were detected as minor but relevant constituents in roasted coffee. Two major isomers, 3-FQL and 4-FQL, were monitored, and their highest concentrations were reached after 7 min of roasting, showing a formation profile similar to that of chlorogenic acid lactones (CQL). Despite 4-FQA being present at higher levels than 3-FQA across all samples, 3-FQL dominated the FQL fraction. In light-medium roasted Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon and Longberry, 3-FQL reached 29 mg/100 g coffee in both cases, while 4-FQL reached 13 mg/100 g and 11 mg/100 g coffee, respectively. Quantification of 3-FQL in Robusta coffee was not possible because of chromatographic coelution. Overall, the approximate 70:30 ratio of 3-FQL to 4-FQL in arabica coffees paralleled that observed for the corresponding chlorogenic acid derivatives.

Screening of Flavonoid Content. The contents of five types of flavonoids, namely myricetin, quercetin, luteolin, kaempferol, and apigenin, in methanol extracts of 62 Malaysian edible plants are shown in Table 1. Among the 62 plant extracts tested, all the species showed significant amounts of flavonoids except sweet potato shoots, winged bean, string bean, petai, peria, bayam duri, betel leaves, plainain flower, and oyster mushroom. The results clearly indicated that some of the tested plants were rich in these natural antioxidant flavonoids, and the qualities and quantities of the flavonoids in these plants seemed to be very different among the kinds of samples used.

where SA is the AUC for the sample or standard dilution and CA is the AUC for the control reaction using buffer alone. The median effective concentration (EC50) was determined from the dose-response curve of concentration. The lipophilic PSC assay was performed by first solubilizing lipophilic compounds with 12% (v/v) randomly methylated â-cyclodextrin in 50% (v/v) acetone in water. The fluorescent dye was prepared by hydrolyzing 11 µL of 2. mM dichlorofluorescin diacetate with 1. mL of 1. mM KOH and then diluted to a total volume of 8 mL with 75 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.4). The reaction mix of the lipo-PSC assay contained 100 µL of appropriate dilutions of extracts in 12% randomly methylated â-cyclodextrin, 100 µL of dichlorofluorescin, and 50 µL of 200 mM 2,2′-azobis(amidinopropane). In addition to nine CGA identified in the green samples, seven CGL have been identified in roasted coffee. CGL reached their maximum levels approximately 7 min after the start of the roasting process (i.e., light medium roast equal to ∼14% weight loss). Longer roasting times resulted in lower amounts of both CGA and CGL. A typical HPLC chromatogram of CGA and CGL present in light medium roasted coffee is shown in Figure 3. Their chemical structures are shown in Figure 4. Arabica cultivars offered the clearest identification and quantification of lactones, except for one case in the Bourbon cultivar, in which pCoQL seemed to coelute with other compound(s). Because Robusta coffee is richer in phenolic compounds than arabica coffee (10, 44, 45), separation of lactones is more difficult due to coelution. The elution order of CGA and CQL was similar to that reported by Schrader et al. (47), who used mass spectrometry, NMR spectroscopy, and LC-MS for characterization. The exception was 3-CQL, which in our column eluted before 5-FQA and 4-FQA. Spiking the samples with synthetic standards and with green coffee extract made it possible to distinguish between CGA and CQL using a reverse phase column with a slightly different selectivity from that used by Schrader et al. Apparently, these seven CGL have not been previously separated in a single HPLC analysis.

The antioxidant capacity of phenolic compounds is related to their chemical structure (33, 34); thus, to relate the antioxidant activity to the identified phenols in the lentil processed flours, an analysis of principal components was carried out. Principal component analysis is performed on the values of the antioxidant activity and the concentrations of the identified phenolic groups in raw, soaked, cooked, and dehydrated flours . Six components were obtained of which the first two accounted for 96% of the total variance. Figure 2 illustrates the graphic representation of the first two components. In the graphic four groups of phenolic compounds (hydroxycinnamides, flavonols, flavones, and flavanones) demonstrate a higher correlation with the antioxidant activity and the raw sample. In this study, flavones and flavanones show the most influence on the antioxidant activity, whereas catechins and procyanidins appeared less associated to this activity; contrary to that reported by Dueñas et al. (39) in raw lentils. These differences could be due to the drastic decreases of these compounds during the industrial processing.

Soy consumption has been implicated in the prevention of cancer and other chronic conditions due to the low disease risk of Asian populations with high soy intake (Adlercreutz and Mazur, 1997; Lee et al., 1991; Barnes et al., 1994b). This hypothesis is supported by the observation that Asians experience an increase in incidence of these chronic conditions after migrating to the West, suggesting a causal role of environmental factors (Nomura et al., 1978; Ziegler et al., 1993). The strongest protective effect of soy intake was reported for breast, prostate, and colon cancer (Messina et al., 1994; Adlercreutz, 1995; Kurzer and Xu, 1997) and potentially also endometrial cancer (Goodman et al., 1997). Recent case-control studies observed lower endogenous estrogen levels in Japanese women with high soy intake (Nagata et al., 1997) and a 15% reduction in breast cancer risk with every serving of tofu consumed (Wu et al., 1996). The prominent phytochemicals that are believed to contribute to the biological effects observed after soy consumption include isoflavones (Barnes et al., 1994b) and also phytate, saponins, sterols, and protease inhibitors (Messina et al., 1994). Protein Extraction and Electrophoresis. The obtained electrophoretic patterns of white and red onions were similar; therefore, we present only the separations of red onion proteins with reduction, using $\beta$ -ME, and without reduction (Figure 5A) and extracted from garlic and applied to the gel without reduction . It is interesting that the spectra of raw garlic and red onion have specific bands in the range of molecular masses from 50 to 112 kDa that disappeared after heat treatment . The boiling procedure for more than 20 min caused degradation of the proteins in studied vegetables. The 14 kDa bands in raw garlic and onions during electrophoretic separation without reduction had more proteins than the treated samples. The 50, 70, 77, 100, 102, and 112 kDa bands disappeared after treatment, probably as less stable proteins in these vegetables. Literature data indicate that the superoxide dismutase (SOD) antioxidant activities during boiling, microwaving, and baking were diminished for garlic by about 86, 96, and 90% and for onions by about 60, 77, and 26%, respectively (37), describing the changes of amino acid composition during processing (36). This means that even minimal time of heating effects the protein pattern intensity, but it is visible only for nonreduced samples. Similar data were obtained in our previous studies (15, 16).

Two commercial composite samples of soft wheat (70% Canadian Eastern soft red spring and 30% Canadian Eastern soft white winter) and hard wheat (90% Canadian Western hard red spring and 10% Canadian Eastern hard red winter) were milled to obtain several fractions. Phenolic compounds were separated into free, soluble ester and insoluble-bound fractions. Soluble ester and insoluble-bound phenolics were isolated into diethyl ether following alkaline hydrolysis. Total phenolic content was quantified with the Folin–Ciocalteu assay and expressed as ferulic acid equivalents (FAE). Antioxidant properties of each phenolic fraction were assessed by multiple assays, including Trolox equivalent antioxidant capacity, DPPH radical scavenging, reducing power, oxygen radical absorbance capacity, inhibition of oxidation of human LDL and DNA, Rancimat stability, inhibition of photochemiluminescence, and Fe(II) chelation. In the bran fraction, bound phenolics reached 11 mg FAE/g and 12 mg FAE/g defatted material for hard and soft wheats, respectively. In contrast, the corresponding values in flour were close to zero (0 mg FAE/g, within 0.01–0.02 mg/g experimental error). For whole wheat, bound phenolics were about 2 mg FAE/g defatted material in both hard and soft samples, whereas free phenolics ranged only from 0 to approximately 0 mg FAE/g across the milling fractions.

In this work, changes in blackberry ellagitannins caused by juicing (nonclarified and clarified), pureeing, canning, and freezing were characterized, together with the evolution of these products during 6 months of storage. While canning, pureeing, and freezing had only limited impact on ellagitannin content, juice manufacture led to marked depletion. Nonclarified juice retained only 30 % of the original total ellagitannins (corresponding to a 70 % loss), and clarified juice retained just 18 % (an 82 % loss), mainly because seeds rich in ellagitannins were removed with the presscake. Thermally processed products showed minimal further loss during storage, and frozen berries remained essentially unchanged in both ellagitannin content and composition.

Coffee beans from Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon, Coffea arabica cv. Longberry, and Coffea canephora cv. Robusta were roasted to evaluate the conversion of chlorogenic acids into chlorogenic acid lactones (CGL). Individual lactones were identified and quantified by HPLC against synthetic CGL standards. At light medium roast (around 14 % weight loss), 3-caffeoylquinic-1,5-lactone (3-CQL) showed the highest concentration in both Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon and Coffea canephora cv. Robusta, with values of 230 ± 9 and 254 mg/100 g dry weight, respectively. 4-caffeoylquinic-1,5-lactone (4-CQL) was the next most abundant lactone, reaching 116 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon and 139 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea canephora cv. Robusta. At this roasting point, the maximum level of chlorogenic acid lactones corresponds to approximately 30 % of the available chlorogenic acid precursors in roasted coffee.

Across orange, yellow, and white carrots, the main phenolic constituents were 3',4'-DCQ and 3',5'-DCQ. Purple carrots, however, contained significantly (p < 0.05) greater amounts of C-3'-CQ, chlorogenic acid, caffeic acid, 3'-FQ, 3',4'-DCQ, and 3',5'-DFQ than the other color groups. Chlorogenic acid represented 52.4% of total phenolics in orange carrots, 57.1% in yellow, 51.4% in white, and 72.5% in purple carrots. Moreover, the chlorogenic acid concentration in purple carrots was roughly 6.4, 12.1, and 12 times that found in orange, white, and yellow carrots, respectively. Given previous observations that chlorogenic acid content influences shredded carrot storage behavior (41), purple and orange carrots are expected to store better than the white and yellow cultivars.

The phenolic composition, aroma compounds, and organic acid content of 83 vinegars have been determined. Multivariate analysis techniques have been used to classify these vinegar samples according to raw material (white wine, red wine, apple, honey, alcohol, balsamic, and malt) and production process (with and without aging in wood). Cluster analysis grouped the samples according to production process. Only apple and balsamic vinegars were separated from wine vinegars. Alcohol, honey, and malt vinegars were grouped with no aged wine vinegars. Linear discriminate analysis allowed a 88% differentiation according to raw material and 100% according to aging in wood. Besides, from the results obtained, a major role of the volatile compounds in the differentiation of the vinegar samples according to their aging period in wood can be seen.

Text:
Soy protein drinks and soy supplements have become increasingly popular in North America in recent years and are a major source of isoflavone exposure in Caucasian populations. Although serving sizes were very similar, the composition of soy protein drinks varied in protein, carbohydrate, energy, and total isoflavone amount by factors of 4, 7, 2, and 5, respectively . Three of 8 items analyzed contained fat in amounts of 1–3 g per serving, which may be of importance due to the presence of vitamin E in the lipophilic compartment. We found $\alpha$ -, $\gamma$ -, and $\delta$ -tocopherol levels in fat-containing soy drinks ranging from 1 to 7 $\mu$ g/g applying HPLC techniques developed for plasma micronutrient analysis (Franke et al., 1993). Tocopherol patterns in these items were observed to be typical for those in soy oils (Cooney et al., 1997), indicating that the lipids found in these drinks stem from the soy protein preparation rather than from additives. Most nonfat items were found to contain $\alpha$ -tocopherol acetate (60–985 $\mu$ g/g) as an additive.

Initially, the olive oil analyzed contained 180 ppm of polyphenols, which, together with tocopherols, help explain its high oxidative stability. Phenolics act as potent antioxidants by blocking lipid oxidation chains and binding transition metals, and they can enhance the antioxidant effect of α-tocopherol. Under oxidative conditions, their levels decreased markedly: after 180 days at 25 °C the polyphenol content dropped to 160 ppm; after 6 weeks at 40 °C it declined to 138 ppm; after 18 days at 60 °C it was 131 ppm; and after just 6 days at 80 °C it fell to 102 ppm. This progression clearly indicates that polyphenol degradation accelerates with increasing storage temperature.

Antioxidant Activity. Gli studi che valutano l’attività antiossidante complessiva, includendo sia le molecole idrofile sia quelle lipofile intrinseche agli alimenti, sono pochi; la maggior parte delle ricerche considera solo gli estratti acquosi, ignorando il contributo di alcuni componenti lipidici alla difesa contro lo stress ossidativo (7, 33). Secondo dati USDA relativi a circa 100 alimenti, i trattamenti di cottura possono determinare sia un aumento sia una riduzione dell’attività antiossidante, a seconda del tipo di composto coinvolto e della sua struttura chimica (33). Nel sistema di trasformazione del mais per la produzione di masa e prodotti derivati, la successione di nixtamalizzazione, cottura delle tortillas e successiva frittura dei tortilla chips ha un impatto marcato sull’attività antiossidante. In particolare, la frittura in olio è il passaggio più distruttivo: i tortilla chips presentano meno del 50% della capacità antiossidante originariamente misurata nel chicco crudo. La trasformazione della masa in tortillas può, invece, determinare un leggero incremento della capacità antiossidante, probabilmente legato all’aumento di fenolici solubili liberati da fitocomplessi legati.

The use of black carrot extracts as food colorants is attractive both because of their pigment stability and their potential nutritional benefits. Nevertheless, most trials have relied on crude root extracts or concentrates of black carrot juice and have largely ignored other carrot components with antioxidant activity, in particular the hydroxycinnamic acids that are present in high concentrations. In some cases, antioxidant capacity has been linked to total phenolic levels, while in others it has been associated with total anthocyanin content. Only limited work has focused on the influence of individual compounds on color characteristics such as visual detection limits and hue. In spite of the evident advantages of black carrots as natural color sources, data on the contents of single anthocyanins in the roots are lacking. Total anthocyanins reported in the literature, based on spectrophotometric measurements, span from 1 to 98 mg/100 g fresh weight.
