In raw pardina lentils, catechin and proanthocyanidin derivatives represented the largest share of the phenolic fraction, contributing 69% of the identified phenolics and reaching 74. µg/g. The major individual compound within this group was (+)-catechin 3-glucoside (39. µg/g), followed by a procyanidin trimer and procyanidin B2. These findings corroborate earlier studies by Escarpa and González (27), Amarowicz and Karamac (28), and Martín-Cabrejas et al. (7). Unlike the results of Dueñas et al. (24), prodelphinidins were not found in the raw lentils. Industrial dehydration produced substantial losses in these phenols: (+)-catechin 3-glucoside in particular showed a dramatic 95% decrease, and most procyanidins were no longer detectable at the completion of processing. Such thermal treatments (cooking and dehydration) are known to favor degradation of polymeric proanthocyanidins, hydrolysis of glycosylated flavonoids, and decomposition of aglycones (10, 29). Moreover, air-drying at temperatures higher than 60 °C is considered unfavorable for the efficient recovery of phenolic compounds because of oxidative condensation and thermal breakdown of labile (+)-catechins (32).

Al contrario, Burlat e Summit mostravano concentrazioni di 3 mg/100 g di fw, che rappresentavano circa il 5 e il 3% del contenuto totale di fenoli. In generale, il livello di rutin aumentava dal grado di maturazione parziale a quello pienamente maturo; in Saco, nel 2002, il contenuto passava da 3 a 10 mg/100 g di fw, corrispondendo a un incremento di circa tre volte. Nel corso del periodo di stoccaggio, il contenuto di flavonoli nelle ciliegie, sia mature sia parzialmente mature, si manteneva pressoché costante alle due temperature considerate.

Estimates of Free and Conjugated Flavonol Levels. Free flavonols were detected in the unhydrolyzed samples, while the total flavonol content was determined after acid hydrolytic cleavage of the flavonol conjugates which released the aglycons. The conjugated flavonol level was, thus, estimated by subtracting the amount of flavonol found in the unhydrolyzed sample from the quantity present in the acid-hydrolyzed extract. With each analysis, the flavonol content of the hydrolyzed sample was corrected for sample handling/hydrolysis losses on the basis of the recovery of the morin internal standard, which typically was >90%. Triplicate samples from each bottle of wine were analyzed before and after acid hydrolysis.

Organic Acids. The organic acid content of each vinegar was analyzed in duplicate by capillary electrophoresis using a method previously set up by the authors (10). A Waters Capillary Ion Analyzer (Milford, MA) was equipped with an UV-visible detector of wavelength set at 185 nm. The fused-silica capillary utilized had an effective length of 57 cm (60 cm of total length) with 75 $\mu$ m i.d. Samples were introduced hydrostatically into the capillary (height 10 cm). The injection time was 30 s, and the temperature was 20 °C. The voltage applied was 7 kV, using a negative feed source. Comparison of Bioavailability of Anthocyanins. From the plasma profiles obtained after oral and intravenous administration of bilberry extract (Bilberon 25), both the area under the plasma concentration curve (AUC) and the bioavailability of anthocyanins were calculated and the results are given in Table 2. The bioavailability calculated was in the range from 0. to 1.8%. When the bioavailability of anthocyanins carrying the same aglycone was compared, galactoside tended to show a higher value than glucoside. On the other hand, when the bioavailability of anthocyanins with the same sugar moiety was compared, peonidin tended to show the highest bioavailability; however, the order of other anthocyanins was variable dependent on the attached sugar type. Ferric Reducing Activity Power (FRAP) Assay. The FRAP assay was carried out as described by Benzie and Strain (26) with some modifications as previously reported (5, 27). Briefly, freshly prepared FRAP reagent (2. mL) was mixed with appropriately diluted extract (80 μL). The mixture was allowed to stand for 60 min at room temperature before absorption was measured at 593 nm (Agilent 8453 spectrophotometer, Agilent Technologies). Aqueous solutions of Fe-(II) (FeSO<sub>4</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O) in the concentration range of 125–1000 μmol/L were used for calibration of the FRAP assay. FRAP values were expressed as millimoles of Fe(II) per 100 g of sample (mmol of Fe/100 g of fw). All extracts were diluted and analyzed in duplicate.

Text:
Ellagitannins are an important class of phenolics that have received attention recently due to their purported health benefits (1-3). Ellagitannins are polymers of hexahydroxydiphenic acid that can be hydrolyzed to form ellagic acid. Blackberries contain a complex mixture of ellagitannins that range in molecular weight from 302. (ellagic acid) to 3738. (lambertianin D) (4,5). The ellagitannins in black berries are located predominantly in the seeds (4,6), but some are found in the torus (receptacle tissue), and only a few are present in the flesh (4). Several studies have evaluated the ellagitannin content in blackberries with values ranging from 8 to > 70 mg/100 g of FW (7-9). There are no current studies on processed blackberries that report the amount of ellagitannins in their native forms. However, one study (10) reported that ellagic acid in raspberry jam (not hydrolyzed from ellagitannins) increased 2-fold with processing and 3-fold over 6 months of storage, presumably as a result of ellagitannin depolymerization. This suggests that evaluation of native ellagitannin content changes may offer a greater understanding of the potential bioavailability of these phenolics, because they range in molecular weight and number of hexahydroxydiphenic acid moieties.

In this work, we have quantified the loss of phenolics and antioxidant capacity in brassica vegetables that need to be cooked. Steamed vegetables retained about 80 % of the phenolic and ORAC values of raw vegetables, whereas boiled vegetables retained only 30 % of antioxidants, also losing flavour. From raw to boiled brassica vegetables, a linear negative relationship was found between phenolic content and type of cooking. Therefore, the preferred cooking process for vegetables should be steaming at the mildest temperature and for the shortest possible time in order to protect phenolics and vitamins. This aspect has been elucidated several times in terms of vitamin loss but only seldom in terms of phenolics and ORAC value.

In IQF blackberries stored for 6 months, the total ellagitannin content did not change appreciably. The only notable exception at the level of individual compounds was GalHHDPGlu, which increased by 44%. Consequently, ellagitannins in the frozen fruit appeared very stable, with negligible degradation or depolymerization during storage. This behavior differs from the 30–40% loss of ellagic acid reported for frozen raspberries and strawberries over 9 months (15), but agrees with earlier work on frozen blackberries, where only minimal variation in ellagic acid (released from ellagitannins) was detected after 12 months (27).

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Walnut fruit phenolics are recognized as important antioxidants that help protect unsaturated fatty acids against oxidative degradation (9). The compounds characterized in this work are expected to participate in that protective effect, and several additional health benefits of walnut phenolics have been documented (10, 15–17, 30). We found that phenolic concentrations, particularly of syringic acid, juglone and ellagic acid, were far higher in the pellicle than in the kernel. Ferulic and sinapic acids were present at the lowest levels in both tissues, although earlier studies (31) have highlighted sinapic acid as one of the more potent antioxidant phenolic acids. Total identified phenolics varied notably among cultivars, with Rasna showing more than a twofold higher sum compared with Fernette, reaching 85 mg/100 g in the kernel and 2500 mg/100 g in the pellicle. Gunduc and El (12) have reported total phenolic contents up to 7052 mg/kg in walnut kernel, underscoring the high phenolic potential of this nut.

In roasted Coffea arabica, p-coumaroyl-1,5-lactones (pCoQL) arise from the minor chlorogenic acids p-coumaroylquinic acids (pCoQA), which occur at roughly 30–70 mg/100 g in green arabica and 50–60 mg/100 g in Robusta. Following 7 min of roasting, Bourbon beans contained about 7 mg/100 g of 3-pCoQL and Longberry beans about 4 mg/100 g. For the corresponding 4-pCoQL isomer, the levels were again 7 mg/100 g in Bourbon but only 2 mg/100 g in Longberry, confirming that these lactones remain low-abundance phenolic constituents even under light–medium roast conditions.

Text:
A maximal Fe(II) chelation capacity of 10572 µg EDTA equivalents/g of defatted material was recorded. Free phenolic fractions from both soft and hard wheats were weak Fe(II) chelators, whereas esterified and insoluble-bound fractions showed a chelating potential that increased with their total phenolic content (TPC). This confirmed a positive link between TPC and Fe(II) binding. Alkaline hydrolysis of the wheat matrix freed phenolic aglycons, which could then participate in Fe(II) chelation, while esterified or bound phenolic acids displayed a reduced ability to complex Fe(II). Consistent with reports that glycosylation lowers antioxidant performance in radical trapping assays by blocking reactive OH groups, the same type of glycosylation effect was reflected in diminished Fe(II) chelation.

When flavonoid profiles of different almond cultivars are combined with sales-weighting, a representative picture of flavonoid intake from whole almonds can be obtained (see Table 5). Adopting the standard U.S. Department of Agriculture method that restricts reporting to aglycone forms, whole almonds are estimated to deliver the key aglycones at the following levels (mg/100 g, mg/serving): isorhamnetin 11. (3.32), kaempferol 0. (0.17), catechin 1. (0.55), quercetin 0. (0.20), and epicatechin 0. (0.24). This quantitative framework permits direct comparisons with other commonly consumed foods on a per-weight basis. In such comparisons, almonds appear to provide flavonol amounts similar to red onions, but roughly nine times higher isorhamnetin than white onions (48, 49). The kaempferol and quercetin contents are close to those found in broccoli, and their catechin concentration lies between values reported for brewed black and green tea (19).

Text:
Antioxidant Activity. The hydrophilic and lipophilic antioxidant activities of free and bound phenolics in raw corn and nixtamalized products were expressed as micromoles of vitamin C or E per 100 g of sample. Bound phenolics were the main contributors to overall antioxidant capacity, in agreement with the patterns observed for total phenolics and ferulic acid. After nixtamalization, the hydrophilic antioxidant activity associated with free phenolics increased significantly (p > 0.05). In raw grains, this activity ranged from 41 ± 2 to 49 ± 4 μmol vitamin C equiv/100 g, with high-carotenoid corn showing the greatest values. For masa, tortillas, and tortilla chips, hydrophilic antioxidant activity of free phenolics ranged from 68 to 114 μmol vitamin C/100 g. In contrast, the hydrophilic activity of bound phenolics decreased after lime-cooking, dropping by about 30% in masa and by more than 50% in tortilla chips relative to raw corn. Hydrophilic antioxidant activity accounted for about 98% of total antioxidant capacity, and free lipophilic activity also rose following lime-cooking and further processing into tortillas and chips.

Text:
Losses in total ellagitannins in juices were dramatic, with 82 and 70% lost in clarified and nonclarified juices, respectively, compared to IQF fruit used for processing . With 67% of the original ellagitannin content retained in the presscake, the exclusion of the seeds, where most of the ellagitannins are located (4, 6), accounted for the dramatic losses in ellagitannins in the final product. The concentration of all ellagitannins in the blanched and enzyme-treated mash was 43% greater than that in the frozen fruit, suggesting that the blanching step in combination with the enzyme treatment enhanced the extractability of the ellagitannins, although the other thermal processing treatments discussed previously did not result in increased extractability. According to Rommel and Wrolstad (14), the ellagic acid content of raspberry juices was highly affected by the processing technique, particularly the extent of heating, which dramatically increased total ellagic acid due to enhanced extractability from the cell wall matrix. Pasteurization of nonclarified and clarified juices did not affect levels of total ellagitannins, indicating that the compounds are heat stable.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
When blackberries were processed into juice, total ellagitannin content dropped sharply relative to the IQF starting fruit: clarified juice retained only about 18% of the original ellagitannins (82% loss), and nonclarified juice about 30% (70% loss). Roughly 67% of the initial ellagitannin pool remained in the presscake, consistent with seeds being the main reservoir of these compounds. In contrast, the blanched, enzyme-treated mash showed a 43% increase in total ellagitannins compared with frozen fruit, indicating that this combination of treatments improved their extractability from the tissue. Literature data for raspberry juices suggest a similar behavior for ellagic acid, where more intensive heating promotes release from the cell wall matrix. Pasteurization of both clarified and nonclarified blackberry juices did not further change total ellagitannin levels, supporting the view that these tannins are thermally stable under typical juice processing conditions.

In pigmented corn, anthocyanins are concentrated in the aleurone layer and pericarp. Under nixtamalization conditions, that is, alkaline pH close to 10 combined with heat, these pigments are strongly degraded, and higher calcium hydroxide doses promote even greater losses. In our material, blue and red corn showed the largest decreases in anthocyanins, although blue corn products still retained the highest anthocyanin content in absolute terms. Across the sequential processing steps, average anthocyanin losses reached 77% during lime-cooking, 73% during tortilla baking, and 70% during frying of tortilla chips. These values fall within the range of 73–100% losses previously reported for nixtamalization. Lime-cooking was clearly the most damaging step, whereas the additional processing into tortillas and chips did not significantly further reduce anthocyanin levels (p > 0.05).

Phenolic compounds in walnut fruits have an important antioxidative role in protecting fatty acids from oxidation (9). The studied compounds identified in our experiment can share a part of that role. As well, many health-beneficial effects of walnut phenolics have also been described (10, 15–17, 30). Much higher contents of phenolics, especially of syringic acid, juglone, and ellagic acid, were observed in the pellicle. In pellicle as well as in kernel the lowest contents of ferulic acid and sinapic acid were found among the identified phenolics, but Rice-Evans et al. (31) found that sinapic acid was the one with higher antioxidative activity, among other phenolic acids (ferulic, caffeic, p-coumaric, syringic, and vanillic acid). Moreover, the study showed differences in the sum of all identified phenolics between the cultivars. The highest differences were observed between Rasna and Fernette fruits; in Rasna there were >2-fold higher contents of identified phenolics in both kernel (the sum was 85. mg/100 g) and pellicle (the sum was 2500. mg/100 g). Gunduc and El (12) reported total phenolics content of up to 7052 mg/kg of walnut kernel. The cultivars with higher phenolic contents (individual or sum) may have influence on human health; however, this should be a topic of other investigations. Also, sensory evaluations of fruits with the aim to compare sensory attributes and phenolics contents of walnut fruits should be carried out.

In this work, 19 different phenolic compounds were quantified directly in wort and finished beer using reverse-phase HPLC coupled to coulometric array detection. Separation was performed in 45 min using a binary mobile phase of phosphate buffer, methanol, and acetonitrile with a programmed gradient. An array of eight coulometric detectors in series provided voltammetric information sufficient to deconvolute coeluting peaks. The analytical protocol showed high sensitivity and reliability, with calibration curves characterized by regression coefficients up to 1.000 and low standard deviations for both matrices. On average, worts contained about 22 mg/L of free phenolic acids, whereas beers reached approximately 33 mg/L. These free phenolic acids accounted for roughly 5% of non-tannic, non-flavonoid phenols in wort and about 10% in beer.

Legume flours (5. g) were macerated with $3 \times 50$ mL of a solution of methanol-HCl (1%/100) water (80:20 v/v) using an orbital shaker at room temperature, separating the supernatants by centrifugation (3024g, 10 min, 5 °C). The three combined supernatants were taken to a fixed volume (150 mL) of the methanol solution, yielding a methanol extract where the radical scavenging activity of the extract was determined. An aliquot of the methanolic solutions (50 mL) was extracted three times with ethyl ether ( $3 \times 15$ mL) and ethyl acetate ( $3 \times 15$ mL). The organic phases were combined and dried with anhydrous $\text{Na}2\text{SO}4$ for 20 min and evaporated to dryness under vacuum. The residue was dissolved in 1 mL of methanol/ $\text{H}2\text{O}$ (50:50, v/v) and finally filtered ( $0. \mu\text{m}$ ) for HPLC analysis. The extractions were performed in duplicate.

To characterize ellagitannin migration during storage, the berries and liquid phases of canned blackberry products were analyzed separately and expressed per whole can. In canned blackberries in syrup (CS), berries showed a pronounced decline in total ellagitannins over 6 months, corresponding to a 42% loss, whereas the CS liquid fraction gained ellagitannins, with total levels increasing 2.5-fold from day 1 to 6 months. Canned blackberries in water (CW) displayed no consistent net change in berry ellagitannin content due to high variability, but the CW liquid fraction still exhibited a 2.0-fold increase in total ellagitannins across the same storage period, confirming leaching. After 6 months, only about 10–20% of total ellagitannins were found in the liquid fractions compared with 80–90% remaining in the berries, implying that discarding the canning liquid would remove only a minor portion of total ellagitannins and have limited impact on their overall intake.

In addition, apricot nectars and jams also contained significant amounts of (+)-catechin, quercetin 3-rutinoside, and especially (−)-epicatechin, which was the main flavonoid of all the investigated nectars and jams. Syringic acid was determined in remarkable amounts in apricot nectars and jams that contained 10 and 15% of added pumpkin puree and in detectable amount in those that contained 5% of added pumpkin puree. Considering the share of dry matter of fruit (40% in nectars and 8% in jams) in total dry matter of apricot nectars or jams, it was proven that the syringic acid was stable during nectar or jam processing. Addition of 5% of pumpkin puree in apricot nectars and jams may be not profitable, but it was the lowest detectable amount. Two commercial samples of soft (70% Canadian Eastern soft red spring and 30% Canadian Eastern soft white winter) and hard (90% Canadian western hard red spring and 10% Canadian Eastern hard red winter) wheats were used to obtain different milling fractions. Phenolics extracted belonged to free, soluble esters and insoluble-bound fractions. Soluble esters of phenolics and insoluble-bound phenolics were extracted into diethyl ether after alkaline hydrolysis of samples. The content of phenolics was determined using Folin-Ciocalteu's reagent and expressed as ferulic acid equivalents (FAE). The antioxidant activity of phenolic fractions was evaluated using Trolox equivalent antioxidant capacity, 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl radical scavenging, reducing power, oxygen radical absorbance capacity, inhibition of oxidation of human low-density lipoprotein cholesterol and DNA, Rancimat, inhibition of photochemilumenescence, and iron(II) chelation activity. The bound phenolic content in the bran fraction was 11. ± 0. and 12. ± 0. mg FAE/g defatted material for hard and soft wheats, respectively. The corresponding values for flour were 0. ± 0.01 and 0. ± 0.02 mg FAE/g defatted sample. The bound phenolic content of hard and soft whole wheats was 2. The present study quantified how cooking affects phenolics and antioxidant capacity in brassica vegetables. When the vegetables were steamed, they preserved around 80 % of both the total phenolic content and the ORAC value relative to the raw state. In contrast, boiling led to a retention of only about 30 % of the total antioxidants and was also associated with a noticeable loss of flavour. A clear linear, negative relationship was observed between the intensity of cooking (up to boiling) and phenolic content. Consequently, steaming at mild temperatures and for the shortest time is recommended to better preserve phenolics and vitamins.

Text:
Commercial blends of soft wheat (composed of 70% Canadian Eastern soft red spring and 30% Canadian Eastern soft white winter) and hard wheat (90% Canadian Western hard red spring plus 10% Canadian Eastern hard red winter) were fractionated by milling. Phenolics were classified into free, soluble ester, and insoluble-bound forms. After alkaline hydrolysis, soluble ester and insoluble-bound phenolics were extracted with diethyl ether, and their contents were determined by the Folin–Ciocalteu method, expressed as ferulic acid equivalents (FAE). The antioxidant activity of these fractions was characterized through a wide panel of methods, including Trolox equivalent antioxidant capacity, DPPH scavenging, reducing power, oxygen radical absorbance capacity, protection against oxidation of human LDL and DNA, Rancimat measurements, photochemiluminescence inhibition, and Fe(II) chelation. Bound phenolics in bran reached 11 mg FAE/g defatted material for hard wheat and 12 mg FAE/g for soft wheat. In flour, bound phenolics were essentially negligible (around 0 mg FAE/g within a 0.01–0.02 mg/g error margin). Whole wheat samples from both hard and soft types contained about 2 mg FAE/g defatted material as bound phenolics, while free phenolic levels in all milling fractions were very low, not exceeding approximately 0 mg FAE/g.

Reducing Power of Wheat Extracts. The reducing power of wheat samples was determined following the method of Oyaizu (32) with slight modifications. The assay medium contained 2. mL of sample in a 0. M phosphate buffer (pH 6.6) and 2. mL of 1% potassium ferricyanide. After incubation at 50 °C for 20 min, 2. mL of 10% trichloroacetic acid was added to the mixture followed by centrifugation at 1750g for 10 min. One milliliter of the supernatant was mixed with 2. mL of high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) grade water and 0. mL of 0.1% ferric chloride, and the absorbance of the resultant solution was read at 700 nm. A standard curve was prepared using various concentrations of ascorbic acid, and the reducing power was expressed as $\mu$ mol ascorbic acid equivalents/g of defatted material.

Hydroxycinnamic Compounds. This phenolic group only represented 4% of the identified phenolic compounds in raw lentils . The hydroxycinnamic compounds are mainly constituents of the cell wall, in various bonds and esterified forms, linked to arabinoxylans and lignin. This group included hydroxycinnamic compounds in free forms (trans-p-coumaric and cis-p-coumaric acid) and those linked to other compounds (hydroxyacids) . Most of these phenolic acids have been detected in raw leguminous seeds and their extracts, as reviewed Amarowicz and Pegg (25). In general terms, these compounds decrease with thermal treatment, except the trans-p-coumaric acid derivative. The loss of ellagitannins during storage depended strongly on achene content: purees with more achenes, and thus more ellagitannins, showed a faster decline. In contrast, ellagitannin concentrations in purees prepared only from flesh remained essentially unchanged. After 16 weeks at 22 °C, purees made from berry homogenate and from achene-enriched material retained about 80% and 72% of their initial ellagitannins, respectively. Ellagic acid glycosides were better preserved at 6 °C (around 75–89% of initial levels after 16 weeks) than at 22 °C (57–61%). Meanwhile, free ellagic acid in the purees increased progressively during storage and was roughly doubled after 16 weeks at 22 °C, likely due to hydrolysis of ellagitannins, although its absolute level may be underestimated because of the poor solubility of free ellagic acid.

Anthocyanin Content. Anthocyanin concentrations in the different corn types and their processed products are listed in Table 3. Lime-cooking led to substantial pigment losses, mainly because anthocyanins diffused into the steeping medium (nejayote). Among the varieties, blue corn had the greatest anthocyanin content (36 mg cyanidin-3-glucoside equivalents per 100 g dry weight), with red corn next (9 mg/100 g dry weight). The other corn samples contained only minor amounts, between 0.57 and 4 mg cyanidin-3-glucoside equivalents per 100 g dry weight. When kernels were lime-cooked, blue and red corn lost approximately 80% and 23% of their original anthocyanins, respectively, compared with the raw grains.

other berry fruits can be altered by processing and storage (10, 14, 15). Freezing strawberries and raspberries resulted in a 20% loss in total ellagic acid (after acid hydrolysis of ellagitannins) with 9 months of storage further exacerbating losses (with up to 40% additional degradation of ellagic acid); however, with 9 months of storage of strawberry jams there were no losses in total ellagic acid observed (15). Because there are considerable changes that can occur to the native ellagitannins (i.e., degradation or depolymerization), the effects of processing on ellagitannin composition and content should also prove valuable to understanding their role in health promotion. Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Analysis of Ferulic Acid. Ferulic acid was determined using the method reported previously from our laboratory (5, 6). Briefly, ferulic acid in sample extracts was quantified using RP-HPLC equipped with a 250 mm × 4. mm, 3 µm Supelcosil LC-18-DB column with isocratic elution of 20% (v/v) acetonitrile in water adjusted to pH 2 with trifluoroacetic acid at a flow rate of 0. mL/min. Detection was at a wavelength of 280 nm with a Waters 484 UV-visible detector (Waters Corp., Milford, MA). Detector signals were acquired and integrated by Waters Millenium software. Peak identification of free ferulic acid in sample extracts was based on retention time and chromatography of an authentic ferulic acid standard. Ferulic acid concentrations in samples were calculated by extrapolation on a calibration curve. Twenty microliter injections were used for all analyses.

Because brassica vegetables have a rather intense flavour in the fresh state, they are commonly consumed after cooking. We compared their phenolic content and ORAC values after two different treatments: boiling in water and steaming (Fig. 1). According to Fig. 1(A), boiling caused almost 80 % loss of phenolics in brassica vegetables when compared with fresh vegetables, while steaming caused only 20–30 % loss. Fig. 1(B) shows that the ORAC values of these vegetables changed in a similar way to the phenolic content. A linear relationship between total phenolics and cooking method was observed, with correlation coefficients above 0. for each brassica type.

Text:
Antioxidant Activity. For raw corns and their nixtamalized products, hydrophilic and lipophilic antioxidant activities of free and bound phenolics were monitored as μmol vitamin C or E per 100 g. Bound phenolics dominated the antioxidant response, mirroring earlier results obtained for total phenolics and ferulic acid. Nixtamalization led to a significant rise (p > 0.05) in hydrophilic antioxidant activity from the free phenolic fraction: in raw grains this activity was 41–49 μmol vitamin C equiv/100 g, while in masa, tortillas, and tortilla chips it increased to 68–114 μmol vitamin C/100 g, with high-carotenoid corn again having the highest capacity. In contrast, the hydrophilic antioxidant activity of bound phenolics decreased after lime-cooking, by roughly 30% in masa and by over 50% in tortilla chips compared with raw corn. Overall, hydrophilic activity represented approximately 98% of the total antioxidant capacity, and free lipophilic antioxidant activity was also enhanced by lime-cooking and subsequent processing into tortillas and chips.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Anthocyanin Content. The anthocyanins in corn are mainly located in the aleurone layer and pericarp. Previous work has shown that during nixtamalization of blue corn, most anthocyanins are degraded because of the combined effect of alkaline pH (around 10) and high temperature, which causes structural transformations and breakdown. Increasing the amount of calcium hydroxide in cooking further increases anthocyanin losses. In this study, blue and red corn genotypes showed the highest anthocyanin losses, even though blue corn products still contained the highest absolute anthocyanin contents. On average, anthocyanin losses during lime-cooking, tortilla baking, and tortilla chip frying were 77%, 73%, and 70%, respectively. These values are consistent with earlier reports showing 73–100% loss during nixtamalization. Lime-cooking caused the greatest decrease in anthocyanins, whereas further processing into tortillas and chips did not significantly change anthocyanin levels (p > 0.05).

In assays of copper-induced LDL oxidation, bran extracts exhibited much higher antioxidant activity than whole grain or flour. Nevertheless, cereals were reported to contain only small amounts of phenolic compounds, on the order of 0.2-1. mg gallic acid equivalents/g of crude phenolic extract (41). Kahkonen et al. (41) also documented low antioxidant activity from cereal extracts at 5000 ppm in a methyl linoleate system. These low TPC estimates can be explained by analytical protocols that focus solely on free phenolics. In cereal matrices, most phenolic compounds are bound to cell wall materials (10-13, 42-44). The current work demonstrated that these bound phenolics contribute strongly to the TPCs of whole grains, flours, and brans from soft and hard wheats, clarifying why cereals seem to have low TPCs when only free phenolic acids are considered. Dewanto et al. (45) reported analogous results for corn, emphasizing the dominance of bound phenolics. Sosulski et al. (10) showed that 69.2% of wheat TPCs derive from insoluble-bound phenolics and that soluble conjugated phenolic acids in cereal flours are present at levels 2-5 times those of free phenolic acids.

Extraction of Conjugated Phenolic Acids. The extraction of conjugated phenolic acids was performed according to previous report (22), with slight modifications. Briefly, the raw and cooked bean samples (0. g in triplicate) were hydrolyzed and extracted with 10 mL of 2 N NaOH [contained 10 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) and 1% vitamin C (w/v)], at 40–45 °C for 30 min. The reaction mixture was acidified by adding 2. mL of 7. N HCl. The mixture was vortexed for 5–10 s, and phenolic acids were extracted with ethyl acetate twice (2 × 10 mL). The combined organic layer was concentrated to dryness at 45 °C under vacuum to remove solvents. The dry residue was redissolved in 1. mL of 25% methanol. The methanol solution was filtered through a 0. μm PVDF syringe filter and analyzed for conjugated phenolic acid content by HPLC.

After 8 weeks storage at 6 °C, the AA concentrations were about 2 mg/100 g of fw (67-89% loss) in all purees, regardless of initial AA levels and achene contents in the purees . In strawberry jam the decrease in AA was less extensive, that is, 27% after 3 months of storage at 5 °C (18). TP and antioxidant activities in the purees were quite stable during storage at 6 °C. After 16 weeks, on average, 93, 88, and 91% of the TP, FRAP, and ORAC values, respectively, were retained in the purees. After storage at room temperature for 16 weeks, about 68% of the TP and FRAP values remained in the purees made from flesh, whereas for purees made from achene-enriched homogenate the corresponding number was about 82%. Development of ORAC values in purees during storage was not dependent upon achene level. TP and antioxidant activities in purees were better retained in the purees during storage than the anthocyanins and ascorbic acids. Similar results were obtained in a dessert made from berries, where AA and anthocyanins decreased rapidly during storage, whereas levels of other phenolic compounds and antioxidant activity were only slightly modified (20).

Analytical Methods. To determine the phenolics an HPLC analysis was performed using a Surveyor HPLC system (Thermo Finnigan, San Jose, CA) and a diode array detector scanning the spectra of wavelength in the range from 220 to 360 nm. The system was controlled using the ChromQuest 4. chromatography workstation software system. Separations were carried out using a Chromsep HPLC column SS (250 $\times$ 4. mm, Hypersil 5 ODS) coupled with a Chromsep guard column SS (10 $\times$ 3 mm) from Chrompack (Middelburg, The Netherlands), maintained at 25 °C. The flow rate was 1 mL/min. The injection volume was 20 $\mu$ L. The chromatographic conditions were as previously described by Schieber et al. (25) with minor modifications. Two percent acetic acid was prepared in bidistilled water as solvent A and 0.5% acetic acid in bidistilled water and acetonitrile (ratio 1:1) as solvent B. The gradient used for the phenolics analysis was as follows: from 90% A to 45% A (50 min), from 45% A to 0% A (10 min), from 0% A to 90% A (5 min). The total run time was 65 min, and 15 min of equilibration treatment (90% A) between each analysis was performed.

Text:
Sample Acquisition, Extraction, and Purification. Kernels from the eight most commonly grown California almonds species (Prunus dulcis) (out of 32 varieties), i.e., Butte, Carmel, Fritz, Mission, Monterey, Nonpareil, Padre, and Price, were provided in raw, whole form by the Almond Board of California. The varieties were collected from across a wide variety of orchards throughout the state and pooled so that no individual orchard was disproportionately represented. The collection process occurred during 2004 and 2005. The almonds were stored in the dark at 4 °C until they were separated into individual aliquots for extraction and analysis. In an industrial setting, water blanching is employed to remove the skin , a process that has the potential to extract substantial amounts of flavonoids. To determine the total flavonoid and phenolic acid content and distribution in the almonds, we analyzed skins, blanch water, and kernels (blanched almonds) separately. Briefly, 100 g of whole almonds was blanched in 175 mL of boiling distilled water for 2. min, a procedure designed to mimic the typical industrial blanching process, and the skins were removed by hand. The volume of blanch water produced from 100 g of almonds was recorded and used to calculate the flavonoid content extracted from the skin. After a cleanup step via centrifugation and filtration through a Millex-HV $0. \mu m$ filter (Millipore, Billerica, MA), the total phenol content in the samples was determined by the Folin-Ciocalteu reaction. Individual flavonoids were analyzed by highperformance liquid chromatography (HPLC)/electrochemical detection (ECD) using a 16 channel Coulometric Array Detector System (ESA, Inc., Chelmsford, MA.).

Antioxidant Activity. Le informazioni sull’attività antiossidante degli alimenti che considerino contemporaneamente componenti idrofili e lipofili sono ancora scarse. La maggior parte degli studi valuta solo la frazione idrosolubile, nonostante sia noto che anche alcuni lipidi contribuiscono alla prevenzione di patologie da stress ossidativo (7, 33). I dati USDA su un centinaio di alimenti mostrano che i trattamenti termici possono determinare sia incrementi sia cali dell’attività antiossidante, in funzione del tipo e della struttura degli antiossidanti presenti (33). Nel processo mais → masa → tortilla → tortilla chips, ogni passaggio termico modifica la capacità antiossidante complessiva. La frittura per ottenere i tortilla chips è il passaggio più penalizzante: il prodotto finale conserva meno della metà (<50%) dell’attività antiossidante misurata nel grano crudo. Al contrario, la semplice cottura della masa in tortillas può aumentare leggermente l’attività antiossidante, verosimilmente grazie al rilascio di fenoli solubili da matrici legate.

Text:
Ellagitannins constitute a phenolic class that has attracted considerable interest because of proposed health-promoting effects (1-3). Structurally, they are polymers of hexahydroxydiphenic acid that can be hydrolyzed to yield ellagic acid. Blackberries are rich in a heterogeneous pool of ellagitannins, spanning molecular weights from 302 (ellagic acid) up to 3738 (lambertianin D) (4,5). These compounds are located mainly in the seeds, with smaller proportions in the torus tissue and only minor amounts in the flesh (4,6). Reported ellagitannin contents in fresh blackberries range from 8 to >70 mg/100 g FW (7-9). Data on processed blackberry products describing native ellagitannins are lacking, but one study (10) showed that ellagic acid in raspberry jam (not liberated by hydrolysis) increased 2-fold during processing and 3-fold after 6 months of storage, consistent with progressive ellagitannin depolymerization. Monitoring native ellagitannin profiles is therefore relevant for understanding how processing and storage affect their bioavailability.

According to Table 4, fresh olive oil contained 180 ppm of polyphenols alongside tocopherols, both contributing to its notable resistance to autoxidation. Phenolic compounds slow lipid oxidation by interrupting radical chain reactions and chelating pro-oxidant metal ions, and they can also act synergistically with α-tocopherol. During storage and thermal oxidation, however, polyphenols progressively degraded: their concentration fell from 180 to 160 ppm after 180 days at 25 °C, to 138 ppm after 6 weeks at 40 °C, to 131 ppm after 18 days at 60 °C, and further to 102 ppm after 6 days at 80 °C. These data demonstrate that the rate of polyphenol degradation increases sharply at higher oil oxidation temperatures.

The relative contributions of polyphenol classes in apple peel differ widely among Basque cider apple cultivars. For apple peel (ER, GK, MX1, MX10, PK, UG), dihydrochalcones represent the second most abundant class, at 7-19% of total polyphenols. In black beans, thermal processing strongly affected the retention of anthocyanins, in line with earlier observations on black soybeans (24 ). Each of the thermal-processing treatments significantly (p < 0.05) decreased the concentration of individual anthocyanins. Regular steaming proved to be the most conservative treatment, maintaining relatively higher levels of delphinidin-3-glucoside, malvidin-3,5-diglucoside, and petunidin-3-glucoside. By contrast, pressure steaming completely removed malvidin-3-glucoside and malvidin-3-galactoside, leaving only small residual amounts of delphindin-3-glucoside (22. μg/g), petunidin-3-glucoside (11. μg/g), and malvidin-3-glucoside (6. μg/g) in the pressure-steamed beans. Total anthocyanin contents did not differ significantly between regular boiling and pressure boiling. When compared with the raw black beans, thermal treatments caused severe losses, namely 93.3-99% for delphinidin-3 glucoside, 58.8-100% for malvidin-3,5-diglucoside, 91.5-98.7% for petunidin-3-glucoside, 100% for malvidin-3-galactoside, and 88.2-98.5% for malvidin-3-glucoside, illustrating substantial degradation of the anthocyanin composition.

I dati disponibili sugli effetti della trasformazione sono limitati; informazioni USDA su circa 100 alimenti indicano che la cottura può aumentare o ridurre l’attività antiossidante a seconda della natura e della struttura molecolare dei composti (33). Nel caso del mais per masa, la sequenza di trattamenti termici (nixtamalizzazione con calce, cottura delle tortillas e frittura dei tortilla chips) modifica l’attività antiossidante. In particolare, la frittura profonda ha l’effetto più negativo: i tortilla chips mostrano meno del 50% della capacità antiossidante del chicco crudo. La cottura della masa in tortillas, invece, provoca un leggero aumento dell’attività antiossidante, probabilmente per la liberazione di fenolici solubili da fitocomposti legati.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
In this study the impact of achenes on polyphenolic compounds, ascorbic acids, and antioxidant activities in strawberry purees at production and after storage at 6 and 22 °C for 8 and 16 weeks was investigated. Strawberry purees were made from flesh, berry, and achene-enriched homogenate and contained 0, 1.2, and 2.9% achenes, respectively. At production, strawberry purees made from flesh contained more anthocyanins, p-coumaroyl glycosides, and ascorbic acids, whereas increasing achene levels caused increasing levels of ellagic acid derivatives, proanthocyanidins, flavonols, total phenolics (TP), and antioxidant activities. In addition, the anthocyanins, TP, and ferric reducing ability power (FRAP) in purees with more achenes were better retained during storage. Ascorbic acids and anthocyanins declined rapidly during storage, whereas other polyphenols and antioxidant activities were more stable; that is, the contributions from anthocyanins and ascorbic acids to TP and antioxidant activities decreased. The findings that achenes contributed significantly to polyphenol content and stability of strawberry purees may be interesting in a nutritional and, thus, commercial, perspective.

In our study of soy foods, the overall isoflavone composition followed a stable pattern but the conjugation forms differed with processing. For soy foods, the total isoflavone ratio was 45:45:10 for daidzein/genistein/glycitein, i.e. soy foods contained 45% of total isoflavones as daidzein, 45% as genistein, and 10% as glycitein. Glucosyl malonates dominated the conjugate profile, reaching 65-72% of total isoflavones in unprocessed soybean and seeds (frozen) and in soy flours. When soybeans were boiled for 1 h, boiled soybeans (1 h) exhibited a -8% change in glucosyl malonates, together with a +6% change in glucosides and +1% changes in acetyl-glucosides and aglycons (% change vs raw). Tau pok (fried pressed tofu) showed a distinct pattern, with acetyl-glucosides representing 24% of total isoflavones in tau pok (fried pressed tofu).

Among plant-derived beverages, coffee is particularly rich in chlorogenic acids, which are partially converted into chlorogenic acid lactones (CGL) during roasting. Using Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon, Coffea arabica cv. Longberry, and Coffea canephora cv. Robusta, we monitored CGL formation at different roast degrees by HPLC with synthetic CGL standards as references. At a light medium roast (corresponding to about 14 % weight loss), 3-caffeoylquinic-1,5-lactone (3-CQL) emerged as the main lactone, with concentrations of 230 ± 9 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon and 254 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea canephora cv. Robusta. The next most abundant species was 4-caffeoylquinic-1,5-lactone (4-CQL), reaching 116 mg/100 g and 139 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon and Coffea canephora cv. Robusta, respectively. At this roasting level, the total pool of chlorogenic acid lactones corresponds to approximately 30 % of the available chlorogenic acid precursors.

Free phenolic acids in wort and beer were determined simultaneously for a panel of 19 target compounds using RP-HPLC with coulometric array detection. A 45 min chromatographic run, based on a phosphate buffer–methanol–acetonitrile binary system and a tailored gradient, allowed adequate resolution, while eight coulometric cells in series generated voltammetric data to distinguish coeluting species. The method provided robust calibration (regression coefficients approaching 1.000) and low standard deviations in both worts and beers. Mean levels of free phenolic acids were estimated at 22 mg/L in Italian worts and 33 mg/L in corresponding beers. Expressed as a fraction of total non-tannic, non-flavonoid phenols, these values represent about 5% in wort and 10% in beer.

In general, the metabolites associated to pomegranate juice intake coincide with those previously reported to be produced in rats after pomegranate husk intake. These metabolites (6H-dibenzo[b,d]pyran-6-one derivatives) were reported to be produced by intestine bacteria in rats after consumption of ellagic acid and ellagitannins . In the study achieved with rats, these metabolites were detected in urine, in significant amounts,after 4 days ,suggesting that the rat needed some time to adapt the microflora to metabolise the pomegranate tannins to produce these metabolites. A previous work concerning the disposition of ellagic acid in mice indicated that 22 % of the ingested ellagic acid was excreted in urine after 24h and only one 6Hdibenzo[b,d]pyran-6-one derivative was detected in faeces. Perhaps, the 24-h study was not enough to detect 6H-dibenzo[b,d]pyran-6-one derivatives in both plasma and urine .

It is well established that both processing and storage can alter the phenolic profile of berries (10, 14, 15). In strawberries and raspberries, freezing caused a 20% loss in total ellagic acid (determined after ellagitannin hydrolysis), and extending storage for 9 months produced up to a further 40% degradation of ellagic acid. By contrast, strawberry jam stored for 9 months did not exhibit any loss in total ellagic acid (15). Because native ellagitannins are susceptible to degradation and depolymerization, studying how different processing steps influence ellagitannin levels and composition is crucial for evaluating their health-promoting potential. Accordingly, this work examined the effects of processing and storage on ellagitannins in IQF berries and in blackberry products including juice, canned-in-syrup (CS), canned-in-water (CW), and puree.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Anthocyanins from red cabbage (Brassica oleracea L. var. capitata) were studied in a human crossover trial in which 12 volunteers ingested 100, 200, or 300 g of steamed red cabbage per session. The cabbage contained approximately 1 µmol of anthocyanins per gram of fresh weight. Anthocyanin levels in cabbage extracts and in urine were quantified by HPLC-MS/MS. In the vegetable, six nonacylated and 30 acylated anthocyanins were detected, whereas urine samples contained a subset of these (3 nonacylated and 8 acylated anthocyanins) together with four phase II metabolites. Twenty-four hour urinary excretion of intact anthocyanins rose linearly with dose, reaching 65 nmol for acylated and 79 nmol for nonacylated anthocyanins at the 300 g dose. However, fractional recovery decreased with dose, from 0.041% to 0.020% of intake for acylated and from 0.18% to 0.09% for nonacylated anthocyanins. Metabolites were mainly glucuronidated and methylated forms. Overall, nonacylated anthocyanins showed more than four times higher urinary recovery than acylated counterparts.

Anthocyanins, a group of reddish to purple water-soluble flavonoids, are the primary pigments in black, blue, and purple cereal grains and have been recognized as health-enhancing substances due to their antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anticancer, and hypoglycemic effects. They have been found to be absorbed from the gut into the bloodstream and were detected in the urine at 1.0–6.7 % of the total amount when six healthy human subjects drank 300 mL of a red wine containing 218 mg of anthocyanins. The world production of anthocyanins has been estimated at 10000 tonnes from grapes alone, and the average daily intake has been estimated at 215 mg in summer and 180 mg in winter, emphasizing both their abundance in foods and their relevance for human nutrition.

Task: extract all food–polyphenol–quantity triples from the following paragraph.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Catechins and Proanthocyanidins. The content of catechin and proanthocyanidin compounds represented the highest percentage (69%) of identified phenolics (74. µg/g) in raw lentils. The main compound is (+)-catechin 3-glucoside (39. µg/g), followed by a procyanidin trimer and procyanidin B2. These results are in agreement with the findings of Escarpa and González (27), Amarowicz and Karamac (28), and Martín-Cabrejas et al. (7). However, prodelphinidins are not detected in raw lentils, in contrast to the work of Dueñas et al. (24). Important reductions are observed in the content of these phenols as affected by the industrial dehydration. (+)-Catechin 3-glucoside exhibited the most pronounced decrease (95%), as well as most of procyanidins that were not detected at the end of the industrial process of dehydration. The thermal treatments (cooking and dehydration) would allow degradation reactions of the more polymerized proanthocyanidins, hydrolysis of glycosylated flavonoids, and decomposition of aglycones (10, 29). In general, air-drying at temperatures >60 °C is regarded as unfavorable to efficient extraction of phenolic compounds due to oxidative condensation or decomposition of thermolabile compounds such as (+)-catechins (32).

raw lentils | (+)-catechin 3-glucoside | 39. | µg/g
dehydrated lentils | (+)-catechin 3-glucoside | 95 | % loss

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Effect of Drying Temperature on Flavonoid Content. Phenolic compounds are usually susceptible to different factors (eg., acidic solution and high temperature) during the extraction process. Drying at temperatures below 50 °C yields the highest amount of total phenolics (58). Drying at room temperature may enhance the enzymatic degradation and thus lower the amount of phenolics in the samples. Increasing the temperature above 60 °C lowered the phenolic amount considerably. At high temperatures, certain phenolics may decompose/combine with the other plant components. Cooking lowered the quercetin content of both tomatoes and onions, with greater reduction being detected following microwaving and boiling than after frying (23). This could be due to flavonoid breakdown during cooking and/or conjugated quercetin being extracted from the tomato and onion tissues by hot water more effectively than with hot oil used in the study. Price et al. (59) found that there are only little gross changes in either the overall level or the composition of quercetin glucosides during normal commercial storage. Boiling and frying do not result in gross changes in glucosides composition, although an overall loss of up to 25% is found for both processes, in the former by leaching into the cooking water and in the latter by thermal degradation into products.

Carrots are the major single source of provitamin A, providing 17% of the total vitamin A consumption (21). In carrots, six types of carotenes and related compound exist, $\alpha$ -, $\beta$ -, $\gamma$ -, and $\zeta$ -carotenes, lycopene, and $\beta$ -zeacarotene. Of these, $\alpha$ - and $\beta$ -carotenes are most predominant (22), which theoretically possess 50 and 100% vitamin A activity, respectively (23, 24). Recently, the demand for $\beta$ -carotene has increased due to its reported anticancer activity in certain cases (25, 26) and other health benefits (27, 28). On the other hand, vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is the micronutrient most readily associated with fruits and vegetables. Its content varies considerably among different vegetables (29) and depends also on the variety and agronomic conditions (30).

Marked differences in flavonoid levels among lettuce and endive varieties, and even between individual heads harvested at the same time, are likely attributable to strong gradients within the leaves. In the data reported by Herrmann (1976), lettuce cv. Blanco showed 60 μg/g flavonoids in the outer leaf parts but only 3 μg/g in the inner tissue, while lettuce cv. Valentine exhibited 462 μg/g in the outer parts versus 7 μg/g in the inner tissue. These intra-plant differences probably reflect environmental influences such as unequal sunlight exposure. Since the goal of the present work was to estimate flavonoid levels in lettuce as actually eaten and thus enable dietary intake calculations, determining the flavonoid content of the whole plant was considered the most appropriate approach.

lettuce cv. Blanco inner tissue | flavonoids | 3 | µg/g
lettuce cv. Valentine outer parts | flavonoids | 462 | µg/g
lettuce cv. Valentine inner tissue | flavonoids | 7 | µg/g

Total Polyphenol Content by Folin-Ciocalteu Method. Estimation of the global polyphenol content in apple juices was performed according to the Folin-Ciocalteu method adapted from Singleton and Rossi (16). Centrifuged juice aliquots ( $0. \text{ mL}$ ) were diluted 20-fold in methanol/2.5% aqueous acetic acid (10:90, v/v). Folin-Ciocalteu reagent ( $0. \text{ mL}$ ) was added to a $0. \text{ mL}$ of the diluted cider solution. The mixture was homogenized with a vortex and, after $3 \text{ min}$ for allowing the reaction to take place, $1 \text{ mL}$ of $\text{Na}2\text{CO}3$ ( $200 \text{ g/L}$ ) and $3.25$ or $8. \text{ mL}$ of ultrapure water were added, depending on the cultivar polyphenol content, and homogenized. No relevant changes were observed in most individual ellagitannins; however, GalHHDPGlu increased by 44%. Text:
Coffee is known to have one of the highest concentrations of chlorogenic acids among plant foods. During roasting, part of these chlorogenic acids is converted into chlorogenic acid lactones (CGL). In our study on Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon, Coffea arabica cv. Longberry, and Coffea canephora cv. Robusta, individual CGL were quantified by comparing HPLC peaks with synthetic standards. Seven different CGL were identified. For light medium roasts (about 14 % weight loss), 3-caffeoylquinic-1,5-lactone (3-CQL) was the predominant lactone, reaching peak levels of 230 ± 9 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon and 254 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea canephora cv. Robusta. The second most abundant lactone was 4-caffeoylquinic-1,5-lactone (4-CQL), with contents of 116 mg/100 g and 139 mg/100 g dry weight in Coffea arabica cv. Bourbon and Coffea canephora cv. Robusta, respectively. Overall, at this roast degree, the total amount of chlorogenic acid lactones represents roughly 30 % of the available chlorogenic acid precursors.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Ellagitannins, a subgroup of phenolic compounds, have been studied extensively because of their potential health benefits (1-3). They are built from hexahydroxydiphenic acid units and can be hydrolyzed to release ellagic acid. In blackberries, ellagitannins form a complex mixture with molecular weights ranging from 302 (corresponding to ellagic acid) up to 3738 (lambertianin D) (4,5). The bulk of these compounds is localized in the seeds, with smaller amounts present in the receptacle (torus) and only trace levels in the flesh (4,6). Previous work has reported total ellagitannins in fresh blackberries between 8 and >70 mg/100 g FW (7-9). Although native ellagitannins in processed blackberry products have not been comprehensively quantified, a study on raspberry jam (10) showed that non-hydrolyzed ellagic acid doubled upon processing and tripled after 6 months of storage, consistent with gradual depolymerization of ellagitannins. Tracking native ellagitannin changes could therefore give better insight into their bioavailability and behavior during processing and storage.

raspberry jam | ellagic acid | 2 | fold increase (processing)

Organic Acid Analysis. Organic acids were extracted according to the method of Alasalvar et al. (11). A 10 g sample of grated hazelnut was homogenized in 80 mL of 0.1% phosphoric acid (H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>) for 3 min in an ice bath. The extract was subsequently centrifuged at 1500g for 15 min at 4 °C. The water-soluble layer was carefully collected with a pipet and then filtered through a Whatman no. filter paper. The filtrate was brought to 100 mL with the extraction solvent to give the extract. After that, the filtrate was cleaned by passing 5 mL through a disposable C<sub>18</sub> Sep-Pak cartridge (Waters Corp., Milford, MA), previously conditioned by flushing with 2 mL of acetonitrile followed by 5 mL of HPLC grade water. Finally, the purified extract was refiltered through a Gelman Acrodisc LC13 PVDV 0. µm pore size syringe filter (Pall Life Sciences) and then injected (20 $\mu$ L) into a Supelcogel C-610H column, 300 mm $\times$ 7. mm i.d. (Supelco). The equipment consisted of a Shimadzu LC-20AD pump, an SPD-M20A diode array detector (DAD), a SIL-20A HT autosampler, a CTO-2OAC column oven, a DGU-20A5 degasser, and a CMB-20A communications bus module (Shimadzu Corp.). Column temperature was set at 30 °C. The mobile phase (filtered through a 0. $\mu$ m Millipore filter and degassed prior to use) was a 0.1% phosphoric acid at a flow rate of 0. mL/min. The DAD was set at 210 nm. Identified organic acids were quantified on the basis of peak areas and comparison with a calibration curve obtained with the corresponding standards.

Conjugated forms of gallic and ellagic acid as well as ellagitannins were present both in the ethyl acetate and in the methanol extracts . Ellagic acid was mainly quantified in methanol (65–100%), which may be partly due to conversion of ellagitannins or deconjugation of glycosides in acidified conditions. There was variation and similarities in the composition galloyl esters, ellagitannins, and ellagic acid glycosides in berries of Fragaria and Rubus species (Table 2) and Figure 4). Typical was the predominant occurrence of galloyl esters (peaks 1, 3, 22B, 23) in strawberry. Two major ellagitannins (peaks 16, 17) were detected in all of the berries analyzed. Ellagic acid glycosides were detected only in raspberries, of which the wild one showed the most diverse composition and the highest contents.

See Table 1 (Vaccinium) and Table 2 (Rubus) for individual values. Ribes valdivianum is not included in Figure 1 Ribes, as the TPH for this species is 63% more than the next highest value, Ribes nigrum cv. Willoughby .

Comparing the spectral data of the sample peaks with those obtained for the phenolic acid standards confirmed the reliability of quantification (matches were generally 90-100%). Reliability of the method was further shown by recovery and repeatability tests. Recovery tests were performed for every hydrolysis condition using several samples. Generally the recoveries were good (mean >90%, Table 1). However, it appeared that phenolic acids were more stable during alkaline than acid hydrolysis. The method proved to be repeatable: coefficient of variation for the reference sample varied from 4.0% (p-coumaric acid) to 14.1% (p-hydroxybenzoic acid). For other samples, coefficients of variation were mostly under 10% (Tables 1 and 2). Detection limits for phenolic acids, defined as the signal three times the height of the noise level, were estimated at 0.02-

The table below summarizes the composition of the main soybeans in terms of the three isoflavonoids daidzein, glycitein and genistein, expressed as molar percentage of total isoflavonoids.

Soybean (domestic, sample 1) contains 42.7% daidzein, 2.6% glycitein and 54.7% genistein, while soybean (domestic, sample 2) contains 37.2% daidzein, 2.2% glycitein and 60.6% genistein. Soybean (China, sample 3) has 53.5% daidzein, 8.1% glycitein and 38.4% genistein, whereas soybean (Australia, sample 4) has 48.1% daidzein, 6.4% glycitein and 45.5% genistein.

Soybean (U.S.A., sample 5) shows 51.3% daidzein, 7.3% glycitein and 41.4% genistein, and soybean (Canada, sample 6) shows 48.3% daidzein, 5.0% glycitein and 46.7% genistein. The black, small soybean from China (sample 7) contains 52.9% daidzein, 7.8% glycitein and 39.2% genistein.

Black soybean (domestic, sample 8) contains 40.5% daidzein, 2.6% glycitein and 56.9% genistein, and black soybean (Korea, sample 9) 49.7% daidzein, 2.4% glycitein and 47.9% genistein. Finally, green soybean (domestic, sample 10) contains 29.8% daidzein, 2.2% glycitein and 68.1% genistein, while green soybean (Canada, sample 11) contains 50.7% daidzein, 3.6% glycitein and 45.7% genistein.

The content of condensed tannins, expressed as milligrams of CE per gram of sample, varied quite markedly among natural hazelnut varieties, from a low of 3. for Fos-a to 40. for Kus-. A significant loss (∼97.3%) was observed (p < 0.05) when hazelnuts were roasted . In other words, <3% of condensed tannins were retained in the roasted hazelnuts when the skins were removed. This reveals that most of the condensed tannins are located in the skins of hazelnuts. Several studies have found that phenolic compounds including condensed tannins are mainly located in the skin of the nut (22-25). Hazelnut has been reported to contain the highest amount of condensed tannins among seven tree nuts (hazelnut, almond, cashew, chestnut, pecan, pistachio, and walnut) (26, 27).

methylxanthines were estimated and are summarized in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. Their contents varied in different samples collected from different cities in China and Japan. A matrix containing all the 22 oil samples, each with the 11 above-mentioned parameters, was used to obtain an explanation of the correlation, if any, between the polyphenolic composition of olive oil, the RSA, and AOP of phenolic extract and the stability of olive oils as measured by Rancimat. Data processing was developed in two steps as follows: Data relative to PPs composition as determined by HRGC were processed by PCA, and four principal components were extracted with an explained variance of 66.7% (23. along PC 1, 16. along PC 2, 15. along PC 3, and 11. along PC 4). The loading of each PP on the principal components is reported in Table 5. To detect the importance of derived variables (PCs) on the determination of radical scavenging activity, antioxidant power and stability to oxidation, the PCs were processed by stepwise general leastsquares (SGLSA) multiple regression analysis, SGLSA being aimed at detecting cause-effect relationships. Other authors used SGLSA to study the effect of antioxidants on virgin oil stability (5). To the purpose of this study SGLSA was preferred to PLS, as recommended by other authors for similar investigation (32), because the variables considered in this study were not correlated (principal components are orthogonal for construction). Results of the SGLSA are reported in Table 6. The most significant variables were found to be PC 2 and PC 3, which are positively correlated with RSA. 3′4′-DHPEA-EA weighed on PC 2, while syryingic acid and p-cumaric acid weighed on PC 3. By the results of SGLSA, it is possible to hypothesize that 3′4′-DHPEA-EA, syryngic acid, and p-cumaric acid are the most important

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
In the present study, sowing time had some effect on flavonoid concentration and composition. Total flavonoid content was highest in August and lowest in June, when comparisons were made at growth stage II (current commercial stage of harvest, Figure 2). Total flavonoid content varied up to 31% among sowing times when comparisons were made within each growth stage. The individual flavonoids varied up to 91% (Table 2), which is little compared to the reported 91 fold variation in the isorhamnetin-3-rutinoside content of Diplotaxis tenuifolia between spring (March) and summer (September) harvesting (10). The field season for cv. Emilia spinach in southern Sweden is from May to September, and differences might have been greater if the whole growing season had been monitored in this investigation. Annual fluctuations in radiation, temperature, and other environmental parameters, as well as time of season, are likely to affect these changes. Howard et al. (9) found a higher total phenolic content in spinach harvested in spring than in fall. However, the spinach they harvested in spring was overwintered. Thus, plant age was different between the two harvests, a fact that may also have had an effect on the phenolic content, again showing the difficulty of distinguishing between seasonal variation and ontogenic changes.

The levels of insoluble phenolic compounds were quantified after acid hydrolysis of the extraction residue (26, 28, 29). Ellagic acid equivalents and anthocyanidins were released from the extraction residues of all of the berries , but flavonols were only released from strawberries (Honeoye and Polka 12 mg/kg and Jonsok 5 mg/kg) and hydroxycinnamic acids from none of the berries. Insoluble flavonols (kaempferol) in strawberry are supposed to represent the cell wall bound phenolic compounds. The levels of insoluble (polymeric or cell wall bound) condensed tannins were around 10-20 mg/kg in the berries studied. According to the spectral characteristics, the released anthocyanidins were cyanidin and pelargonidin, which represent the constituent units (epi)catechin (procyanidin) and (epi)afzelechin (propelargonidin), respectively . In strawberries, cloudberries, and arctic bramble, (epi)catechin units dominated (approximately 80%), but in raspberries, both units were detected in approximately equal amounts. In the study of Gu et al. (19), the molar proportion of epiafzelechin was 6% in strawberry and 14% in raspberry for those proanthocyanidins, which were soluble in 70% acetone.

1. Effect of the Lipid Content in the Diet on the Urinary Metabolome. Three-way ANOVA showed that 994 variables (18% of the 5587 variables filtered) are significantly affected by the lipid content of the diets, interaction effect with catechin supplementation and sampling time included. Compared to the LF diet (control), 136-295 variables were significantly affected by the increased lipid content of the diets (i.e., with MF and HF diets) in the absence or presence of catechin at either days 17 or 38. From 18 (at day 17 without catechin) to 41% (at day 17 with catechin added) of these variables were commonly affected by MF and HF diets. Sixteen variables were highly correlated (|r| > 0.8) with the lipid content of the diets whatever the sampling time and the presence or absence of catechin. Among all variables affected by the lipid content in the diet, some were tentatively identified by comparing experimental mass with theoretical mass (ΔmDa ≤ 5 mDa) of the metabolites given in HMDB: deoxycytidine (m/z 228), nicotinic acid (m/z 124), 2,4-dihydroxyquinoline (m/z 162) and pipecolinic acid (m/z 130). Their identities were confirmed by comparison of their retention time and MS-MS fragmentation pattern to that of standards . The other variables could not be identified, either due to the lack of plausible metabolites with closely related mass in common metabolite databases or to the absence of available standards when putative identification was suggested by comparison of exact masses with those registered in these databases.

The effect of roasting on taste-active components of 18 native hazelnut varieties, grown in the Giresun province of Turkey, was assessed. Samples were examined for their sugars, organic acids, condensed tannins, and free phenolic acids. Six sugars (fructose, glucose, sucrose, myo-inositol, raffinose, and stachyose), seven organic acids (oxalic, maleic, citric, malic, lactic, succinic, and acetic), and one phenolic acid (gallic acid) were positively identified in natural and roasted hazelnut varieties; among these, sucrose, malic acid, and gallic acid predominated, respectively. Total sugars among hazelnut varieties ranged from 1. to 4. g/100 g, organic acids from 0. to 2. g/100 g, condensed tannins from 3. to 40. mg of catechin equivalents/g, and gallic acid from 0. to 0. mg/100 g. Differences existed in the sugar and organic acid contents between natural and roasted hazelnut varieties, but they did not follow any particular trend. Significant losses (p < 0.05) in condensed tannins ( $\sim$ 97.3%) and gallic acid ( $\sim$ 66.7%) were noted when the hazelnuts were roasted. The present work suggests that roasting resulted in significant loss in condensed tannins and gallic acid due to the removal of the brown skin. The effect of roasting on sugars and organic acids was not noteworthy.

Cooking of green fresh vegetables has been reported to promote the release of carotenoids from the matrix because of the disruption of carotenoid-protein complexes, leading to better extractability and higher concentrations in cooked samples (6). Accordingly, in the present study, the contents of all carotenoid compounds significantly increased in boiled and steamed broccoli (+32 and 19%, respectively) in comparison to raw ones. The concentration of phytoene and phytofluene almost tripled . The release of carotenoids, mainly lutein, from the cells could partially have contributed to the significant increase of the $b^$ value observed for boiled and steamed florets (Table 1) in addition to other phenomena described above. Conversely, frying determined a 67% loss of the initial carotenoid concentration, probably because of leaching into oil and to a higher processing temperature. In this case, phytoene was completely lost, whereas phytofluene exhibited a similar behavior as in boiling and steaming .

Effect of Fermentation on the Levels of Tea Catechins and Alkaloids in TTE 12 Tea Leaves. From the aforementioned data , it seems that the degree of fermentation has a profound effect on the levels of catechins and alkaloids. Because samples of commercial teas have been obtained from different locations, the origins and manufacturing processes of these tea samples are completely unclear. Therefore, we decided to use one species of fresh tea leaves, namely, TTE 12, to study the effect of fermentation process on the levels of these constituents. The results are illustrated in Table 5. The reasons for selecting TTE 12 as starting material are as follows: The tea plant TTE 12 was derived from Camellia sinensis by hybridization at Taiwan Tea Experiment Station in 1981. This hybrid tea species is highly resistant to various insect infections and very productive in leaf yield with moderate tea polyphenol contents; therefore, TTE 12 is now widely cultivated in many tea gardens in Taiwan. In this study, the fermentation processes are carried out by tea-making experts in the Taiwan Tea Experiment Station. The resulting tea products are classified A, B, C, and D according to the degree of fermentation, namely, 0, 10, 25, and 85%, correspondingly. These four classes of tea products are equivalent to the commercial longjing, paochong, oolong, and black teas, respectively. The levels of all catechins including EGCG, EGC, ECG, EC, C, and GCG are progressively reduced during the fermentation process, whereas the level of GA is elevated . The levels of both TP and TB are also progressively reduced, whereas that of caffeine is not changed in the low degree (10-25%) of fermentation but is significantly elevated in the high degree (85%) of fermentation up to 16 mg/ 100 mg . The biochemical mechanism of this elevation is interesting and deserves further investigation.

mean value of 3866 mg/kg of FW reported for seven cultivated blueberry cultivars (1). The levels of total anthocyanins in both sugar and sugar-free jams were similar after processing, with 79% retention compared to levels found in fresh berries. Percent retention of individual anthocyanin glycosides varied considerably, with galactosides generally being better retained than arabinosides . Petunidin 3-glucoside, which was a minor constituent, showed the lowest retention. Our results are generally consistent with those of Ichiyanagi et al. (20), who reported that the acid-catalyzed hydrolysis rate of anthocyanins was affected more by the type of sugar attached rather than aglycon structure, with the rate of hydrolysis following the order arabinosides > galactosides>glucosides. Although the exact mechanism is unclear, it appears that the larger hexose sugar imparts greater resistance to hydrolysis than the smaller pentose sugar.

Raw carrots had low value of ascorbic acid (2. and 30. mg/ $100 \, \mathrm{g}$ for fresh and dry matter, respectively) in comparison to other vegetables (11). The ascorbic acid concentration was slightly but significantly ( $p \leq 0.05$ ) affected by boiling (-9%) and steaming (-38%), whereas it was not detectable in fried carrots. The loss of ascorbic acid can probably be ascribed to water leaching and its thermal degradation, as already reported (4).

Task: extract all food–polyphenol–quantity triples from the following paragraph.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Only gallic acid was detected in the free form in both natural and roasted hazelnut samples. The content of gallic acid varied considerably among natural hazelnut varieties, being lowest in Tombul (0. mg/100 g) and highest in Karafındık (0. mg/ 100 g). Significant differences (p < 0.05) existed between natural and roasted hazelnut varieties. Around 66.7% of gallic acid was lost upon roasting . Several factors may affect the gallic acid content upon roasting such as content of gallic acid in the skin, its thermal decomposition, and eventually its liberation from esters, glucosides, and bounded forms. We did not control these processes, but we believe that the broad range of the gallic acid lost in roasted hazelnut varieties could be caused by different contents of this acid in the skin. The hazelnut samples with high levels of loss were probably characterized by the high content of gallic acid in the skins. In contrast, for hazelnut samples with low level of loss, the majority of gallic acid was probably located in the kernels and only heat treatment caused their decreases. Alasalvar et al. (28) did not detect any free phenolics in Tombul hazelnut, but gallic acid, p-coumaric acid, and sinapic acid were found in the esterified form. Therefore, free phenolics present in hazelnut may not contribute significantly to the taste of natural and roasted hazelnuts.

Task: extract all food–polyphenol–quantity triples from the following paragraph.

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
Boiling had the most detrimental effect on carrot polyphenols, resulting in a complete loss of each compound likely because of their diffusion in the boiling water. Steaming and frying had a less negative effect on total phenolics (-43 and -31%, respectively), exclusively because of the loss of chlorogenic acid (-95 and -93% for the two processes, respectively). Phenolic acids are dissolved in vacuoles and apoplast (29). Cooking of vegetables determines softening and breaking of cellular components with the consequent release of these molecules into the boiling water. The higher softening observed for boiled carrots (Figure 1A) well explains the complete loss of polyphenols in comparison to steamed and fried samples.

carrot (fried) | total phenolics | 31 | % loss
carrot (steamed) | chlorogenic acid | 95 | % loss
carrot (fried) | chlorogenic acid | 93 | % loss

Chunk type: paragraph
Text:
galactose, the average percent retention after 6 months of storage followed the order cyanidin (65%), delphinidin (59%), peonidin (55%), and malvidin (52%). For the two anthocyanidins containing arabinose, delphinidin showed greater retention (50%) than malvidin (45%). Our results are generally consistent with those of Tröst et al. (38), who found that cyanidin anthocyanins were the most stable during storage of blueberry-aronia nectar, followed by peonidin, petunidin, delphinidin, and malvidin, the only discrepancy being that we found delphinidin to be more stable than peonidin. In comparing similar anthocyanidins with different sugars attached, we observed that galactosides were more stable than arabinosides. The mean percent retentions of the galactosides and arabinosides of delphinidin following 6 months of storage were 59 and 50%, respectively, and the mean percent retentions of the galactosides and arabinosides of malvidin were 52 and 45%, respectively. Tröst et al. (38) also reported that anthocyanin galactosides in blueberry—aronia nectars were more stable over storage than arabinosides, but they found glucosides to be the most stable glycoside. We detected only one glucoside in our study, petunidin 3-glucoside, which showed the lowest mean percent retention (20%) after 6 months of storage, but was present at very low concentrations compared to the other anthocyanin glycosides. Although some of the apparent losses of individual anthocyanins during storage were actually due to the formation of anthocyanin-procyanidin polymers, further losses may result from hydrolytic reactions resulting in conversion of anthocyanin glycosides to chalcones, which spontaneously degrade into phenolic acids and aldehydes (39). We also cannot rule out the possibility that heat-stable forms of polyphenol oxidase or peroxidase played a role in the degradation of anthocyanins. Further research is needed to identify the mechanisms responsible for anthocyanin degradation during storage.

Ascorbic acid was not dramatically affected by cooking processes. Steaming and frying had a similar effect on the ascorbic acid concentration, determining losses of about 15%, whereas no significant losses were recorded after boiling ( $p \ge 0.05$ ). As already noticed for carrots, boiling had a surprisingly lower detrimental effect on the ascorbic acid concentration than other cooking methods. It is well-known that heat induces a significant loss of ascorbic acid (29), but this loss was also found to be time-dependent in vegetables (35). Thus, the lower time of boiling in comparison to steaming could explain the lower losses of ascorbic acid content observed in carrots and courgettes.

The composition of tea varies with species, season, age of the leaf (plucking position), climate, and horticultural practices (Lin et al., 1996). Green tea contains polyphenols, which include flavanols, flavadiols, flavonoids (Hertog et al., 1993), and phenolic acids; these compounds may account for up to 30% of the dry weight. The polyphenols are the most biologically active group of the tea components, especially certain catechins. The major tea catechins are (-)-epigallocatechin 3-gallate (EGCG), (-)-epigallocatechin (EGC), (-)-epicatechin (EC), (-)-gallocatechin (GC), and (+)-catechin (C). In the manufacturing of black tea, the monomeric flavan-3-ols undergo polyphenol oxidase-dependent oxidative polymerization leading to the formation of bisflavanols, theaflavins, thearubigins. and other oligomers in the process commonly known as fermentation.
